4.3 Good and Poor Ways to Experiment
Just as there are good and poor ways to gather a sample in an observational sur￾vey, there are good and poor ways to conduct an experiment. First, let’s recall the 
definition of an experimental study from Section 4.1: We assign each subject to an 
experimental condition, called a treatment. We then observe the outcome on the 
response variable. The goal of the experiment is to investigate the association—
how the treatment affects the response. An advantage of an experimental study 
over a nonexperimental study is that it provides stronger evidence for causation.
In an experiment, subjects are often referred to as experimental units. This 
name emphasizes that the objects measured need not be human beings. They 
could, for example, be schools, stores, mice, or computer chips.
The Elements of a Good Experiment
Let’s consider another example to help us learn what makes a good experiment. 
It is common knowledge that smoking is a difficult habit to break. Studies have 
reported that regardless of what smokers do to quit, most relapse within a year. 
Some scientists have suggested that smokers are less likely to relapse if they take 
an antidepressant regularly after they quit. How can you design an experiment to 
study whether antidepressants help smokers to quit?
For this type of study, as in most medical experiments, it is not feasible to ran￾domly sample the population (all smokers who would like to quit) because they 
cannot be readily identified. We need to use a convenience sample. For instance, 
a medical center might advertise to attract volunteers from the smokers who 
would like to quit.
Control comparison group Suppose you have 400 volunteers who would like to 
quit smoking. You could ask them to quit, starting today. You could have each start 
taking an antidepressant and then a year from now check how many have relapsed. 
Perhaps 42% of them would relapse. But this is not enough information.8
 You need 
to be able to compare this result to the percentage who would relapse if they were 
not taking the antidepressant.
8
Chapter 12 explains another reason a control group is needed. The regression effect implies that, 
over time, poor subjects tend to improve and good subjects tend to get worse, in relative terms.

Section 4.3 Good and Poor Ways to Experiment 199
An experiment normally has a primary treatment of interest, such as receiving 
an antidepressant. But it should also have a second treatment for comparison to 
help you analyze the effectiveness of the primary treatment. So the volunteers 
should be split into two groups: One group receives the antidepressant, and the 
other group does not. You could give the second group a pill that looks like the 
antidepressant but that does not have any active ingredient—a placebo. This 
second group, using the placebo treatment, is called the control group. After sub￾jects are assigned to the treatments and observed for a certain period of time, the 
relapse rates are compared. Because the only distinction between the groups, at 
least by design, is taking the antidepressant, the difference between the relapse 
rate of two groups is attributed to the treatment.
Why bother to give the placebo to the control group if the pill doesn’t contain 
any active ingredient? This is partly so that the two treatments appear identical 
to the subjects. (As we’ll discuss, subjects should not know which treatment they 
are receiving.) This is also because people who take a placebo tend to respond 
better than those who receive nothing, perhaps for psychological reasons. This 
is called the placebo effect. For instance, of the subjects not receiving the an￾tidepressant, perhaps 75% would relapse within a year, but if they received a 
placebo pill perhaps 55% of them would relapse. If the relapse rate was 42% for 
subjects who received antidepressants, then in comparing relapse rates for the 
antidepressant and control groups, it makes a big difference how you define the 
control group. Using these numbers, you would say the reduction in relapse was 
33% (75% − 42%) when comparing it to nothing, but 13% (55% − 42%) when 
compared to the placebo group.
In some experiments, a control group may receive an existing treatment rather 
than a placebo. For instance, a smoking cessation study might analyze whether 
an antidepressant works better than a nicotine patch in helping smokers to quit. 
It may be unethical not to provide the standard of care, in this case a nicotine 
patch, if it has already been shown in previous studies to be more effective than 
a placebo. Or the experiment could compare all three treatments: antidepressant, 
nicotine patch, and a placebo.
Randomization In the smoking cessation experiment, how should the 400 study 
subjects be assigned to the treatment groups? Should you personally decide which 
treatment each subject receives? This could result in bias. If you are conducting 
the study to show that the antidepressant is effective, you might consciously or 
subconsciously place smokers you believe will be more likely to succeed into the 
group that receives the antidepressant.
It is better to use randomization to assign the subjects: Randomly assign 200 of 
the 400 subjects to receive the antidepressant and the other 200 subjects to form the 
control group. Randomization helps to prevent bias from one treatment group tend￾ing to be different from the other in some way, such as having better health or being 
younger. In using randomization, we attempt to balance the treatment groups by 
making them similar with respect to their distribution on potential lurking variables. 
This enables us to attribute any difference in their relapse rates to the treatments 
they are using, not to lurking variables or to researcher bias.
You might think you can do better than randomization by using your own 
judgment to assign subjects to the treatment groups. For instance, when you iden￾tify a potential lurking variable, you could try to balance the groups according 
to its values. If age is that variable, every time you put someone of a particular 
age in one treatment group, you could put someone of the same age in the other 
treatment group. There are two problems with this: (1) many variables are likely 
to be important, and it is difficult to balance groups on all of them at once, and 
(2) you may not have thought of other relevant lurking variables. Even if you can 
balance the groups on the variables you identified, the groups could be unbal￾anced on these other variables, causing the overall results to be biased in favor of 
one treatment.

4.4 Other Ways to Conduct Experimental 
and Nonexperimental Studies
In this chapter, we’ve learned the basics of ways to conduct nonexperimental 
and experimental studies. This final section shows ways these methods are often 
extended in practice so they are even more powerful. We’ll first learn about 
alternatives to simple random sampling in sample surveys and then about types 
of observational studies that enable us to study questions for which experiments 
with humans are not feasible. Finally, we’ll learn how to study the effects of two 
or more explanatory variables with a single experiment.
Sample Surveys: Other Random Sampling 
Designs Useful in Practice
Simple random sampling gives every possible sample the same chance of selection. 
In practice, more complex random sampling designs are often easier to implement 
or are more efficient, requiring a smaller sampling size for the same precision. 
Sometimes they are even preferable to simple random sampling.
Cluster random sampling To use simple random sampling, we need a sampling 
frame—the list of all, or nearly all, subjects in the population. In some cases, this 
information is not available. It may be easier to identify clusters of subjects. A 
study of residents of a country can identify counties or census tracts. A study of 
students can identify schools. A study of the elderly living in institutions can iden￾tify nursing homes. We can obtain a sample by randomly selecting the clusters and 
observing each subject in the clusters chosen.
For instance, suppose you would like to sample about 1% of the families in 
your city. You could use city blocks as clusters. Using a map to label and number 
city blocks, you could select a simple random sample of 1% of the blocks and 
then select every family on each of those blocks for your observations.
Cluster Random Sample
Divide the population into a large number of clusters, such as city blocks. Select a simple 
random sample of the clusters. Use the subjects in those clusters as the sample. This is a 
cluster random sample.
For personal interviews, when the subjects within a cluster are close geograph￾ically, cluster sampling is less expensive per observation than simple random 
sampling. By interviewing every family in a particular city block, you can obtain 
many observations quickly and with little travel.
SUMMARY: Advantages and Disadvantages of a Cluster 
Random Sample
Cluster random sampling is a preferable sampling design if
j A reliable sampling frame is not available, or
j The cost of selecting a simple random sample is excessive.
The disadvantages are:
j We usually require a larger sample size with cluster sampling for the same level 
of precision.
j Selecting a small number of clusters might result in a sample that is more homoge￾neous than the population.

Section 4.4 Other Ways to Conduct Experimental and Nonexperimental Studies 205
Stratified random sampling Suppose we are interested in estimating the mean 
number of hours a week that students in your school work on outside employ￾ment. The plan is to use the student directory to take a simple random sample of 
n = 40 students and analyze how the mean compares for freshmen, sophomores, 
juniors, and seniors. Merely by chance, you may get only a few observations from 
one of the classes, making it hard to estimate the mean well for that class. If the 
student directory also identifies students by their class, you could amend the 
sampling scheme to take a simple random sample of 10 students from each class, 
still having an overall n = 40. The four classes are called strata of the population. 
This type of sample is called a stratified random sample.
Stratified Random Sample
A stratified random sample divides the population into separate groups, called strata, 
based on some attribute or characteristic about the subjects, and then selects a simple 
random sample from each stratum.
Stratified sampling is particularly useful when the typical values of the re￾sponse variable differ substantially across the strata. A limitation of stratifica￾tion is that you must have a sampling frame and know the stratum into which 
each subject in the sampling frame belongs. You might want to stratify students 
in your school by whether the student has a job, to make sure you get enough 
students who work and who don’t work. However, this information may not be 
available for each student.
SUMMARY: Advantages and Disadvantages of a Stratified 
Random Sample
Stratified random sampling has the
j Advantage that you can include in your sample enough subjects in each group 
(stratum) you want to evaluate.
j Disadvantage that you must have a sampling frame and know the stratum into 
which each subject belongs.
What’s the difference between a stratified sample and a cluster sample? A 
stratified sample uses every stratum. By contrast, a cluster sample uses a sam￾ple of the clusters rather than all of them. Figure 4.2 illustrates the distinction 
among sampling subjects (simple random sample), sampling clusters of subjects 
(cluster random sample), and sampling subjects from within strata (stratified 
random sample).
In addition, a cluster sample uses predetermined groups to create a single sam￾pling frame, whereas a stratified sample creates multiple sampling frames by strata 
based on a subject characteristic. In the previous examples, city blocks already exist 
and can be listed as the sampling frame. The sampling frames for class year have to 
be defined separately before random selection is performed.
Comparison of different random sampling methods A good sampling design 
ensures that each subject in a population has an opportunity to be selected. The 
design should incorporate randomness. Table 4.1 summarizes the random sampling 
methods we’ve presented.
In practice, sampling designs often have two or more stages. When carrying 
out a large survey for predicting national elections, the Gallup organization often 
(1) identifies election districts as clusters and takes a simple random sample of

206 Chapter 4 Gathering Data
them, and (2) takes a simple random sample of households within each selected 
election district rather than sampling every household in a district, which might 
be infeasible.
Marketing companies also commonly use two-stage cluster sampling, first 
randomly selecting test market cities (the clusters) and then randomly selecting 
consumers within each test market city. Many major surveys, such as the General 
Social Survey, Gallup polls, and the Current Population Survey, incorporate both 
stratification and clustering.
In future chapters, when we use the term random sampling, we’ll mean simple 
random sampling. The formulas for most statistical methods assume simple random 
sampling. Similar formulas exist for other types of random sampling, but they are 
complex and beyond the scope of this text.

Retrospective and Prospective Observational Studies
We’ve seen that an experiment can investigate cause and effect better than an 
observational study. With an observational study, it’s possible that an association 
is due to some lurking variable. However, observational studies do have advan￾tages. It’s often not practical to conduct an experiment. For instance, with human 
subjects it’s not ethical to design an experiment to study the long-term effect of 
cell phone use on getting cancer. Nevertheless, it is possible to design an observa￾tional study that controls for identified lurking variables.
Rather than taking a cross section of a population at some time, such as with 
a sample survey, some studies are backward looking (retrospective) or forward 
looking (prospective). Observational studies in medicine are often retrospective. 
How can we study whether there is an association between long-term cell phone 
use and brain cancer if we cannot perform an experiment? We can form a sample 
of subjects who have brain cancer and a similar sample of subjects who do not 
and then compare the past use of cell phones for the two groups. This approach 
was first applied to study smoking and lung cancer.

A case-control study is a retrospective observational study in which subjects who have

Prospective studies A retrospective study, such as a case-control study, looks

Observational Studies and Causation
Can we ever definitively establish causation with an observational study? No, we 
cannot. For example, because the smoking and lung cancer study in Example 8 
was observational, cigarette companies argued that a lurking variable could 
have caused this association. So why are doctors so confident in declaring that 
smoking causes lung cancer? For a combination of reasons: (1) Experiments 
conducted using animals have shown an association, (2) in many countries, over 
time, female smoking has increased relative to male smoking, and the incidence 
of lung cancer has increased in women compared to men. Other studies, both 
retrospective and prospective, have added more evidence. For example, when a

The two observations for a particular subject are called a matched pair because

A matched-pairs design in which subjects cross over during the experiment 
from using one treatment to using another treatment is called a crossover design. 
Crossover design helps remove certain sources of potential bias. Using the same

results because those variables take the same values for each treatment. For in￾stance, any difference observed between the drug and the placebo responses is 
not because subjects taking the drug had better overall health. Another example

An additional application of a matched-pairs design occurs in agricultural ex￾periments that compare the crop yield for two fertilizer types. In each field, two 
plots are marked, one for each fertilizer. Two plots in the same field are likely to 
be more similar in soil quality and moisture than two plots from different fields. 
If we instead used a completely randomized design to assign entire fields to each 
fertilizer treatment, there’s the possibility that by chance one fertilizer will be 
applied to fields that have better soil. This is especially true when the experiment 
can’t use many fields.
Blocking in an Experiment
The matched-pairs design extends to the comparison of more than two treat￾ments. The migraine headache crossover study could investigate relief for sub￾jects who take a low dose of an oral drug, a high dose of that drug, and a placebo. 
The crop yield study could have several fertilizer types.
In experiments with matching, a set of matched experimental units is referred 
to as a block. A block design with random assignment of treatments to units 
within blocks is called a randomized block design. In the migraine headache 
study, each person is a block. In the crop yield study, each field is a block. A pur￾pose of using blocks is to provide similar experimental units for the treatments, 
so they’re on an equal footing in any subsequent comparisons.
To reduce possible bias, treatments are usually randomly assigned within a block.
In the migraine headache study, the order in which the treatments are taken would 
be randomized. Bias could occur if all subjects received one treatment before an￾other. An example of potential bias in a crossover study is a positive carry-over 
effect if the first drug taken has lingering effects that can help improve results for 
the second drug taken. Likewise, in a crop yield study, the fertilizers are randomly 
assigned to the plots in a field.

CHAPTER SUMMARY 
This chapter introduced methods for gathering data.
j An experiment assigns subjects to experimental conditions (such 
as drug or placebo) called treatments. These are categories of 
the explanatory variable. The outcome on the response variable 
is then observed for each subject.
j An observational study is a type of nonexperimental study 
that observes subjects on the response and explanatory vari￾ables. The study samples the population of interest, but merely 
observes rather than applies treatments to those subjects.
Since association does not imply causation, with observational 
studies we must be aware of potential lurking variables that 
influence the association. In an experiment, a researcher uses 
randomization in assigning experimental units (the subjects) 
to the treatments. This helps balance the treatments on lurking 
variables. A randomized experiment can provide support for 
causation. To reduce bias, experiments should be double-blind, 
with neither the subject nor the data collector knowing to which 
treatment a subject was assigned.
A sample survey is a type of nonexperimental study that takes 
a sample from a population. Good methods for selecting samples 
incorporate random sampling.
j A simple random sample of n subjects from a population is one 
in which each possible sample of size n has the same chance of 
being selected.
j A cluster random sample takes a simple random sample of 
clusters (such as city blocks) and uses subjects in those clusters 
as the sample.
j A stratified random sample divides the population into separate 
groups, called strata, and then selects a simple random sample 
from each stratum.
Be cautious of results from studies that use a convenience sample, 
such as a volunteer sample, which Internet polls use. Even with 
random sampling, biases can occur due to sample undercoverage, 
nonresponse by many subjects in the sample, and responses that 
are biased because of question wording or subjects’ lying.
Most sample surveys take a cross section of subjects at a partic￾ular time. A census is a complete enumeration of an entire popula￾tion. Prospective studies follow subjects into the future, as is true 
with many experiments. Medical studies often use retrospective
observational studies, which look at subjects’ behavior in the past.
j A case-control study is an example of a retrospective study. 
Subjects who have a response outcome of interest, such as 
cancer, serve as cases. Other subjects not having that outcome 
serve as controls. The cases and controls are compared on an 
explanatory variable, such as whether they had been smokers.
A categorical explanatory variable in an experiment is also called a 
factor. Multifactor experiments have at least two explanatory vari￾ables. With a completely randomized design, subjects are assigned 
randomly to categories of each explanatory variable. Some designs 
instead use blocks—sets of experimental units that are matched. 
Matched-pairs designs have two observations in each block. Often 
this is the same subject observed for each of two treatments, such as 
in a crossover study.
Data are only as good as the method used to obtain them. 
Unless we use a good study design, conclusions may be faulty.

[L1] Poor Ways to Sample
[L2] How the sample is obtained can also result in bias. Two sampling methods that may 
[L3] be necessary but are not ideal are a convenience sample and a volunteer sample.
[L4] Convenience samples Have you ever been stopped on the street or at a shop￾ping mall to participate in a survey? Such a survey is likely not a random sample 
[L5] but rather a convenience sample. It is easy for the interviewer to obtain data 
[L6] relatively cheaply. But the sample may poorly represent the population. Biases 
[L7] may result because of the time and location of the interview and the judgment 
[L8] of the interviewer about whom to interview. For example, working people might 
[L9] be underrepresented if the interviews are conducted on workdays between 9 a.m. 
[L10] and 5 p.m. Poor people may be underrepresented if the interviewer conducts 
[L11] interviews at an upscale shopping mall. Homosexuals might not be selected in a 
[L12] study about romantic relationships if the interviewer is homophobic.
[L13] Volunteer samples Have you ever answered a survey you’ve seen posted on 
[L14] the Internet, such as at the home page for a news organization? A sample of this 
[L15] type, called a volunteer sample, is the most common type of convenience sample. 
[L16] As the name implies, subjects volunteer to be in the sample. One segment of the 
[L17] population may be more likely to volunteer than other segments because they 
[L18] have stronger opinions about the issue or are more likely to visit that Internet 
[L19] site. This results in sampling bias. For instance, a survey by the Pew Research 
[L20] Center (January 6, 2003) estimated that 46% of Republicans said they like to 
[L21] register their opinions in online surveys, compared with only 28% of Democrats. 
[L22] (Why? One possible lurking variable is time spent on the Internet. Perhaps 
[L23] Republicans spend more time on the Internet than Democrats do.) Thus, results 
[L24] of online surveys may be more weighted in the direction of Republicans’ beliefs 
[L25] than the general population.
[L26] Convenience samples are not ideal. Sometimes, however, they are necessary, 
[L27] both in observational studies and in experiments. This is often true in medical 
[L28] studies. Suppose we want to investigate how well a new drug performs compared 
[L29] to a standard drug for subjects who suffer from high blood pressure. We won’t 
[L30] find a sampling frame of all who suffer from high blood pressure and take a sim￾ple random sample of them. We may, however, be able to sample such subjects at 
[L31] medical centers or by using volunteers. Even then, randomization should be used 
[L32] wherever possible. For the study patients, we can randomly select who is given 
[L33] the new drug and who is given the standard one.
[L34] Some samples are poor not only because of their convenience but also be￾cause they use a sampling frame that does not reflect the population. An exam￾ple of this was a poll in 1936 to predict the result of a presidential election.<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 17 / 45>Section 4.2 Good and Poor Ways to Sample 195
[L35] A poor sample b The Literary Digest Poll
[L36] Picture the Scenario
[L37] The Literary Digest magazine conducted a poll to predict the result of the 1936 
[L38] presidential election between Franklin Roosevelt (Democrat and incumbent) 
[L39] and Alf Landon (Republican). At the time, the magazine’s polls were famous 
[L40] because they had correctly predicted three successive elections. In 1936, 
[L41] Literary Digest mailed questionnaires to 10 million people and asked how they 
[L42] planned to vote. The sampling frame was constructed from telephone directo￾ries, country club memberships, and automobile registrations. Approximately 
[L43] 2.3 million people returned the questionnaire.

[L2] As we will soon discuss, an experimental study gives the researcher more control 
[L3] over outside influences. This control can allow more accuracy in studying the 
[L4] association.
[L5] Advantage of Experiments Over 
[L6] Observational Studies
[L7] In an observational study, lurking variables can affect the results. Study 1 in 
[L8] Example 1 found an association between cell phone use and eye cancer. However, 
[L9] there could be lifestyle, genetic, or health differences between the subjects with eye 
[L10] cancer and those without it, and between those who use cell phones a lot and those 
[L11] who do not. A lurking variable could affect the observed association. For example, 
[L12] a possible lifestyle lurking variable is computer use. Perhaps those who use cell 
[L13] phones often also use computers frequently. Perhaps high exposure to computer 
[L14] screens increases the chance of eye cancer. In that case, the higher prevalence of 
[L15] eye cancer for heavier users of cell phones could be due to their higher use of com￾puters, not their higher use of cell phones.
[L16] By contrast, an experiment reduces the potential for lurking variables to affect 
[L17] the results. Why? We’ll see that with a type of “random” selection to determine 
[L18] which subjects receive each treatment, we are attempting to form and balance 
[L19] groups of subjects receiving the different treatments; that is, the groups have 
[L20] similar distributions on other variables, such as lifestyle, genetic, or health char￾acteristics. For instance, suppose the researchers in cell phone Study 3 decided 
[L21] to have 24 subjects receive the “on” condition and 23 subjects receive the “off” 
[L22] condition instead of having each subject receive both treatments. The health of 
[L23] the subjects could be a factor in how the brain responds to the treatments and 
[L24] the amount of brain activity that appears on the scans. If we randomly determine 
[L25] which subjects receive the “on” condition and which do not, the two groups of 
[L26] subjects are expected to have similar distributions on health. One group will not 
[L27] be much healthier, on average, than the other group. When the groups are bal￾anced on a lurking variable, there is no association between the lurking variable 
[L28] and the explanatory variable (for instance, between health of the subject and 
[L29] whether the subject receives the “on” condition). Then, the lurking variable will 
[L30] not affect how the explanatory variable is associated with the response variable. 
[L31] One treatment group will not tend to have more brain activity because of health 
[L32] differences, on the average.
[L33] In Study 3, described in Example 1, by using the same subjects for both treat￾ments, the researchers were attempting to further control the variability from the 
[L34] subject’s health. In this experimental study, it was important to randomize the 
[L35] order in which the subject received the treatment.
[L36] Establishing cause and effect is central to science. But it’s not possible to 
[L37] establish cause and effect definitively with observational studies. There’s al￾ways the possibility that some lurking variable could be responsible for the 
[L38] association. If people who make greater use of cell phones have a higher rate of 
[L39] eye cancer, it may be because of some variable that we failed to measure in our 
[L40] study, such as computer use. As we learned in Section 3.4, association does not 
[L41] imply causation.
[L42] Because it’s easier to address the potential impact of lurking variables in an 
[L43] experiment than in an observational study, we can study the effect of an explan￾atory variable on a response variable more accurately with an experiment than 
[L44] with an observational study.

[L2] Once you’ve identified the population, the second step is to compile a list of sub￾jects so you can sample from it. This list is called the sampling frame.
[L3] Sampling Frame
[L4] The sampling frame is the list of subjects in the population from which the sample is 
[L5] taken.
[L6] Ideally, the sampling frame lists the entire population of interest. In practice, 
[L7] as in a census, it’s usually hard to identify every subject in the population.
[L8] Suppose you plan to sample students at your school, asking students to com￾plete a questionnaire about various issues. The population is all students at the 
[L9] school. One possible sampling frame is the student directory. Another one is a list 
[L10] of registered students.
[L11] Once you have a sampling frame, you need to specify a method for selecting 
[L12] subjects from it. The method used is called the sampling design. Here’s one possi￾ble sampling design for sampling students at your school: You select all students 
[L13] in your statistics class. Do you think your class is necessarily reflective of the 
[L14] entire student body? Do you have a representative mixture of freshmen through 
[L15] seniors, males and females, athletes and nonathletes, working and nonworking 
[L16] students, political party affiliations, and so on? With this sampling design, it’s 
[L17] doubtful.
[L18] When you pick a sample merely by convenience, the results may not be rep￾resentative of the population. Some response outcomes may occur much more 
[L19] frequently than in the population, and some may occur much less. Consider a 
[L20] survey question about the number of hours a week that you work at an outside 
[L21] job. If your class is primarily juniors and seniors, they may be more likely to work 
[L22] than freshmen or sophomores. The mean response in the sample may be much 
[L23] larger than in the overall student population. Information from the sample may 
[L24] be misleading.<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 11 / 45>Section 4.2 Good and Poor Ways to Sample 189

[L26] You’re more likely to obtain a representative sample if you let chance, rather than 
[L27] convenience, determine the sample. The sampling design should give each student 
[L28] an equal chance to be in the sample. It should also enable the data analyst to figure 
[L29] out how likely it is that descriptive statistics (such as sample means) fall close to 
[L30] corresponding values you’d like to make inferences about for the entire popula￾tion (such as population means). These are reasons for using random sampling.
[L31] You may have been part of a selection process in which your name was put in 
[L32] a box or hat along with many other names, and someone blindly picked a name 
[L33] for a prize. If the names were thoroughly mixed before the selection, this emu￾lates a random type of sampling called a simple random sample. 
[L34] Simple Random Sample
[L35] A simple random sample of n subjects from a population is one in which each possible 
[L36] sample of that size has the same chance of being selected.
[L37] 5HFDOO
[L38] As in Chapters 2 and 3, n denotes the 
[L39] number of observations in the sample, 
[L40] called the sample size. b
[L41] A simple random sample is often just called a random sample. The “simple” 
[L42] adjective distinguishes this type of sampling from more complex random sampling 
[L43] designs presented in Section 4.4.
[L44] Simple random 
[L45] samples b Drawing Prize Winners
[L46] Picture the Scenario
[L47] A campus club decides to raise money for a local charity by selling tickets to 
[L48] a dinner banquet and raffle. The Athletic Department has donated two pairs 
[L49] of football season tickets as prizes. The winners will be drawn randomly from 
[L50] everyone who purchased a ticket, and each ticket can win only once.

[L1] A phone survey using landlines will not reach homeless people, 
[L2] prison inmates, or people who don’t have landline phones. If its sampling frame 
[L3] consists of the names in a phone directory, it will not reach those who don’t have 
[L4] landlines. Most major polling agencies use randomized dialing. Responses by 
[L5] those who are not in the sampling frame might be quite different from those who 
[L6] are in the frame. Bias resulting from the sampling method, such as nonrandom 
[L7] sampling or undercoverage, is called sampling bias.
[L8] Nonresponse bias A second type of bias occurs when some sampled subjects 
[L9] cannot be reached or refuse to participate. This is called nonresponse bias. The 
[L10] subjects who are willing to participate may be different from the overall sample 
[L11] in some systematic way, perhaps having strong emotional convictions about the 
[L12] issues being surveyed. Even those who do participate may not respond to some 
[L13] questions, resulting in nonresponse bias due to missing data. All major surveys 
[L14] suffer from some nonresponse bias. The General Social Survey has a nonre￾sponse rate of about 20–30%. The nonresponse rate is much higher for many 
[L15] telephone surveys. By contrast, government-conducted surveys often have lower 
[L16] nonresponse rates. The Current Population Survey has a nonresponse rate of 
[L17] only about 7%. To reduce nonresponse bias, investigators try to make follow-up 
[L18] contact with the subjects who do not return questionnaires.
[L19] Results have dubious worth when there is substantial nonresponse. For instance, 
[L20] in her best-selling and controversial book Women and Love (1987), author and 
[L21] feminist Shere Hite presented results of a survey of adult women in the United 
[L22] States. One of her conclusions was that 70% of women who had been married at 
[L23] least five years have extramarital affairs. She based this conclusion on responses to 
[L24] questionnaires returned from a sample of 4500 women. This sounds impressively 
[L25] large. However, the questionnaire was mailed to about 100,000 women. We cannot 
[L26] know whether this sample of 4.5% of the women who responded is representative 
[L27] of the 100,000 who received the questionnaire, much less the entire population of 
[L28] adult American women. In fact, Hite was criticized for her research methodology 
[L29] of using a nonrandom sample and the large nonresponse rate.
[L30] Response bias A third type of potential bias is in the actual responses made. 
[L31] This is called response bias. An interviewer might ask the questions in a leading 
[L32] way, such that subjects are more likely to respond a certain way. Or, subjects may 
[L33] lie because they think their response is socially unacceptable, or they may give 
[L34] the response that they think the interviewer prefers.
[L35] If you design an interview or questionnaire, you should strive to construct 
[L36] questions that are clear and understandable. Avoid questions that are confusing, 
[L37] long, or leading. The wording of a question can greatly affect the responses. A 
[L38] Roper poll was designed to determine the percentage of Americans who ex￾press some doubt that the Holocaust occurred in World War II. In response to 
[L39] the question, “Does it seem possible or does it seem impossible to you that the 
[L40] Nazi extermination of the Jews never happened?” 22% said it was possible the 
[L41] Holocaust never happened. The Roper organization later admitted that the ques￾tion was worded in a confusing manner. When it asked, “Does it seem possible 
[L42] to you that the Nazi extermination of the Jews never happened, or do you feel 
[L43] certain that it happened?” only 1% said it was possible it never happened.4
[L44] Even the order in which questions are asked can dramatically influence re￾sults.

[L76] During one scan, the cell phones were

[L105] Chapters 2 and 3 introduced graphical and numerical ways of describing data. We 
[L106] described shape, center, and variability, looked for patterns and unusual observa￾tions, and explored associations between variables. For these and other statistical 
[L107] analyses to be useful, we must have “good data.” But what’s the best way to 
[L108] gather data to ensure they are “good”? The studies described in Example 1 used 
[L109] two methods. The first two studies merely observed subjects, whereas the third 
[L110] study conducted an experiment with them. We’ll now learn about such methods, 
[L111] study their pros and cons, and see both good and bad ways to use them. This will 
[L112] help us understand when we can trust the conclusions of a study and when we 
[L113] need to be skeptical.
[L114] 2. Is the study ethically feasible?
[L115] 3. How can you design the study 
[L116] to be efficient?
[L117] 4. What types of biases or lurking 
[L118] variables might exist?
[L119] Thinking Ahead
[L120] A knowledge of different study de￾signs for gathering data helps us un￾derstand how contradictory results 
[L121] can happen in scientific research 
[L122] studies and determine which studies 
[L123] deserve our trust. In this chapter, we’ll 
[L124] learn that the study design can have 
[L125] a major impact on its results. Unless 
[L126] the study is well designed and im￾plemented, the results may be mean￾ingless or, worse yet, misleading. 
[L127] Throughout Chapter 4, we will return 
[L128] to the cell phone studies introduced in 
[L129] Example 1 to ask more questions and 
[L130] understand how study design can af￾fect what are appropriate conclusions 
[L131] to infer from an analysis of the data.
[L132] 4.1 Experimental and Observational Studies
[L133] We use statistics to learn about a population. The German and British studies in 
[L134] Example 1 examined subjects’ cell phone use and whether the subjects had brain 
[L135] or eye cancer. Since it would be too costly and time-consuming to seek out all
[L136] individuals in the populations of Germany or Great Britain, the researchers used 
[L137] samples to gather data. These studies, like many, have two variables of primary 
[L138] interest—a response variable and an explanatory variable. The response variable 
[L139] is whether a subject has cancer (eye or brain). The explanatory variable is the 
[L140] amount of cell phone use.
[L141] Types of Studies: Experimental and Observational
[L142] Some studies, such as Study 3 in Example 1, perform an experiment. Subjects are 
[L143] assigned to experimental conditions, such as when both cell phones are deacti￾vated (“off” condition) or the right cell phone is activated (“on” condition), that 
[L144] we want to compare on the response outcome. These experimental conditions are 
[L145] called treatments. They correspond to different values of the explanatory variable.
[L146] 5HFDOO
[L147] From Section 1.2, the population consists 
[L148] of all the subjects of interest. We collect 
[L149] data on a subset of the population, which 
[L150] we call the sample.
[L151] From the beginning of Chapter 3, the 
[L152] response variable measures the outcome 
[L153] of interest. Studies investigate how that 
[L154] outcome depends on the explanatory 
[L155] variable. b
[L156] Experimental Study
[L157] A researcher conducts an experimental study, or more simply, an experiment, by assigning 
[L158] subjects to certain experimental conditions and then observing outcomes on the response 
[L159] variable (or variables). The experimental conditions, which correspond to assigned values of 
[L160] the explanatory variable, are called treatments.
[L161] For example, Study 3 used 47 participants as the subjects. In this experimental 
[L162] study, each participant was assigned to both treatments. These are the categories

[L164] Section 4.1 Experimental and Observational Studies 181
[L165] of the explanatory variable, whether the cell phone is off or on. The purpose of 
[L166] the experiment was to examine the association between this variable and the 
[L167] response variable—the amount of brain activity changes—to determine whether 
[L168] it increased.
[L169] An experiment assigns each subject to a treatment (or to both treatments as 
[L170] in the cross-over design employed in Study 3) and then observes the response. 
[L171] By contrast, many studies merely observe the values on the response variable 
[L172] and the explanatory variable for the sampled subjects without doing anything to 
[L173] them. Such studies are called observational studies. They are nonexperimental.
[L174] Observational Study
[L175] In an observational study, the researcher observes values of the response variable and 
[L176] explanatory variables for the sampled subjects, without anything being done to the sub￾jects (such as imposing a treatment).
[L177] In short, an observational study merely observes rather than experiments with 
[L178] the study subjects. An experimental study assigns each subject to one or more 
[L179] treatments and then observes the outcome on the response variable.
[L180] Identifying experimental 
[L181] versus observational 
[L182] studies
[L183] b
[L184] Cell Phone Use
[L185] Picture the Scenario
[L186] Example 1 described three studies about whether relationships might exist 
[L187] between cell phone use and physiological activity in the human body. We’ve 
[L188] seen that Study 3 was an experiment. Studies 1 and 2 both examined the 
[L189] amount of cell phone use for cancer patients and for noncancer patients us￾ing a questionnaire.
[L190] Questions to Explore
[L191] a. Were Studies 1 and 2 experimental or observational studies?
[L192] b. How were Studies 1 and 2 fundamentally different from Study 3 in 
[L193] terms of how the treatments were determined for each subject?
[L194] Think It Through
[L195] a. In Studies 1 and 2, information on the amount of cell phone use was 
[L196] gathered by giving a questionnaire to the sampled subjects. The sub￾jects (people) decided how much they would use a cell phone and thus 
[L197] determined their amount of radiation exposure. The studies merely 
[L198] observed this exposure. No experiment was performed. So, Studies 1 
[L199] and 2 were observational studies.
[L200] b. In Study 3, each subject was given both treatments (the “off” condi￾tion and the “on” condition). The researchers did not merely observe 
[L201] the subjects for the amount of brain activity but exposed the subjects 
[L202] to both treatments and determined which treatment each would re￾ceive first: Some received the call during the first PET scan and some 
[L203] during the second scan. The researchers imposed the treatments on 
[L204] the subjects. So, Study 3 was an experimental study.*
[L205] Example 2 
[L206] *The researchers noted that “Results of this study provide evidence that acute cell phone expo￾sure affects brain metabolic activity. However, these results provide no information about their 
[L207] relevance to potential carcinogenic effects (or lack thereof) from chronic cell phone use.”

[L210] Let’s consider another study. From its description, we’ll try to determine 
[L211] whether it is an experiment or an observational study.
[L212] Insight
[L213] One reason that results of different medical studies sometimes disagree is 
[L214] that they are not the same type of study. Experimental studies allow direct 
[L215] causal inference to be made, whereas observational studies do not allow 
[L216] causal inference. As we’ll see, there are different types of both observational 
[L217] and experimental studies, and some are more trustworthy than others.
[L218] c Try Exercises 4.1 and 4.3
[L219] 1
[L220] Study by R. Yamaguchi et al., reported in Journal of School Health, vol. 73, pp. 159–164, 2003.
[L221] Experiment or 
[L222] observational study b Drug Testing and Student Drug Use
[L223] Picture the Scenario
[L224] “Student Drug Testing Not Effective in Reducing Drug Use” was the headline 
[L225] in a news release from the University of Michigan. It reported results from a 
[L226] study of 76,000 students in 497 high schools and 225 middle schools nation￾wide.1
[L227]  Each student in the study filled out a questionnaire. One question asked 
[L228] whether the student used drugs. The study found that drug use was similar 
[L229] in schools that tested for drugs and in schools that did not test for drugs. For 
[L230] instance, the table in the margin shows the frequency of drug use for sampled 
[L231] twelfth graders from the two types of schools. In addition, the figure in the 
[L232] margin shows the conditional proportions of drug use for these students.
[L233] Questions to Explore
[L234] a. What were the response and explanatory variables?
[L235] b. Was this an observational study or an experiment?

[L237] Drug Use
[L238] Drug Tests? Yes No Total
[L239] Yes 2,092 3,561 5,653
[L240] No 6,452 10,985 17,437
[L241] Think It Through
[L242] a. The study compared the percentage of students who used drugs in 
[L243] schools that tested for drugs and in schools that did not test for drugs. 
[L244] Whether the student used drugs was the response variable. The ex￾planatory variable was whether the student’s school tested for drugs. 
[L245] Both variables were categorical, with categories “yes” and “no.” 
[L246] For each grade, the data were summarized in a contingency table, as 
[L247] shown in the margin for twelfth graders.
[L248] b. For each student, the study merely observed whether his or her school 
[L249] tested for drugs and whether he or she used drugs. So this was an ob￾servational study.
[L250] Insight
[L251] An experiment would have assigned schools to use or not use drug testing 
[L252] rather than leaving the decision to the schools. For instance, the study could 
[L253] have randomly selected half the schools to perform drug testing and half not to 
[L254] perform it and then, a year later, measured the student drug use in each school.

[L258] Section 4.1 Experimental and Observational Studies 183
[L259] As we will soon discuss, an experimental study gives the researcher more control 
[L260] over outside influences. This control can allow more accuracy in studying the 
[L261] association.
[L262] Advantage of Experiments Over 
[L263] Observational Studies
[L264] In an observational study, lurking variables can affect the results. Study 1 in 
[L265] Example 1 found an association between cell phone use and eye cancer. However, 
[L266] there could be lifestyle, genetic, or health differences between the subjects with eye 
[L267] cancer and those without it, and between those who use cell phones a lot and those 
[L268] who do not. A lurking variable could affect the observed association. For example, 
[L269] a possible lifestyle lurking variable is computer use. Perhaps those who use cell 
[L270] phones often also use computers frequently. Perhaps high exposure to computer 
[L271] screens increases the chance of eye cancer. In that case, the higher prevalence of 
[L272] eye cancer for heavier users of cell phones could be due to their higher use of com￾puters, not their higher use of cell phones.
[L273] By contrast, an experiment reduces the potential for lurking variables to affect 
[L274] the results. Why? We’ll see that with a type of “random” selection to determine 
[L275] which subjects receive each treatment, we are attempting to form and balance 
[L276] groups of subjects receiving the different treatments; that is, the groups have 
[L277] similar distributions on other variables, such as lifestyle, genetic, or health char￾acteristics. For instance, suppose the researchers in cell phone Study 3 decided 
[L278] to have 24 subjects receive the “on” condition and 23 subjects receive the “off” 
[L279] condition instead of having each subject receive both treatments. The health of 
[L280] the subjects could be a factor in how the brain responds to the treatments and 
[L281] the amount of brain activity that appears on the scans. If we randomly determine 
[L282] which subjects receive the “on” condition and which do not, the two groups of 
[L283] subjects are expected to have similar distributions on health. One group will not 
[L284] be much healthier, on average, than the other group. When the groups are bal￾anced on a lurking variable, there is no association between the lurking variable 
[L285] and the explanatory variable (for instance, between health of the subject and 
[L286] whether the subject receives the “on” condition). Then, the lurking variable will 
[L287] not affect how the explanatory variable is associated with the response variable. 
[L288] One treatment group will not tend to have more brain activity because of health 
[L289] differences, on the average.
[L290] In Study 3, described in Example 1, by using the same subjects for both treat￾ments, the researchers were attempting to further control the variability from the 
[L291] subject’s health. In this experimental study, it was important to randomize the 
[L292] order in which the subject received the treatment.
[L293] Establishing cause and effect is central to science. But it’s not possible to 
[L294] establish cause and effect definitively with observational studies. There’s al￾ways the possibility that some lurking variable could be responsible for the 
[L295] association. If people who make greater use of cell phones have a higher rate of 
[L296] eye cancer, it may be because of some variable that we failed to measure in our 
[L297] study, such as computer use. As we learned in Section 3.4, association does not 
[L298] imply causation.
[L299] Because it’s easier to address the potential impact of lurking variables in an 
[L300] experiment than in an observational study, we can study the effect of an explan￾atory variable on a response variable more accurately with an experiment than 
[L301] with an observational study. With an experiment, the researcher has control over 
[L302] which treatment each subject receives. If we find an association between the 
[L303] explanatory variable and the response variable, we can be more sure that we’ve 
[L304] discovered a causal relationship than if we merely find an association in an ob￾servational study. Consequently, the best method for determining causality is to 
[L305] conduct an experiment.
[L306] 5HFDOO
[L307] From Section 3.4, a lurking variable is 
[L308] a variable not observed in the study that 
[L309] influences the association between the 
[L310] response and explanatory variables due 
[L311] to its own association with each of those 
[L312] variables. b
[L313] &DXWLRQ
[L314] In Example 3, the problem with the 
[L315] conclusion they made is that schools with 
[L316] high rates of drug use might be more 
[L317] inclined to employ drug tests to address 
[L318] the problem. It is conceivable that drug 
[L319] tests reduced the rate of drug use from 
[L320] 0.74 to 0.37, cutting the rate in half. It is 
[L321] also conceivable that drug use rates started 
[L322] at 0.37 and didn’t change at all due to 
[L323] the drug test program. The problem with 
[L324] this observational study is that we don’t 
[L325] know which of the previous conceivable 
[L326] scenarios, or plethora of other ones, 
[L327] occurred. b

[L329] 184 Chapter 4 Gathering Data
[L330] Determining Which Type of Study Is Possible
[L331] If experiments are preferable, why ever conduct an observational study? Why 
[L332] bother to measure whether cell phone usage was greater for those with cancer 
[L333] than for those not having it? Why not instead conduct an experiment, such as 
[L334] the following: Pick half the students from your school at random and tell them to 
[L335] use a cell phone each day for the next 50 years. Tell the other half of the student 
[L336] body never to use cell phones. Fifty years from now, analyze whether cancer was 
[L337] more common for those who used cell phones.
[L338] There are obvious difficulties with such an experiment:
[L339] j It’s not ethical for a study to expose over a long period of time some of the 
[L340] subjects to something (such as cell phone radiation) that we suspect may be 
[L341] harmful.
[L342] j It’s difficult in practice to make sure that the subjects behave as told. How can 
[L343] you monitor them to ensure that they adhere to their treatment assignment 
[L344] over the 50-year experimental period?
[L345] j Who wants to wait 50 years to get an answer?
[L346] For these reasons, medical experiments are often performed over a short time 
[L347] period or often with exposure to treatments that would not be out of the ordinary 
[L348] (such as a one-time exposure to cell phone activity). To measure the effects on 
[L349] people of longer exposure to potentially harmful treatments, often the experiment 
[L350] uses animals such as mice instead of people. Because inferences about human 
[L351] populations are more trustworthy when we use samples of human subjects than 
[L352] when we use samples of animal subjects, scientists often resort to observational 
[L353] studies. Then we are not deliberately placing people in harm’s way, but observing 
[L354] people who have chosen on their own to take part in the activity of interest. In 
[L355] today’s information age, a lot of data is readily available to assist (or impede) 
[L356] people from making decisions about the relationship between variables. These 
[L357] data provide only observational comparisons. We’ll study methods for designing a 
[L358] good observational study in Section 4.4. This can yield useful information when an 
[L359] experiment is not practical.
[L360] Finally, another reason nonexperimental studies are common is that many 
[L361] questions of interest do not involve trying to assess causality. For instance, if we 
[L362] want to gauge the public’s opinion on some issue, or if we want to conduct a mar￾keting study to see how people rate a new product, it’s completely adequate to 
[L363] use a study that samples (appropriately) the population of interest.
[L364] Using Data Already Available
[L365] Of course, you will not conduct a study every time you want to answer some 
[L366] question, such as whether cell phone use is dangerous. It’s human nature to rely 
[L367] instead on already available data. The most readily available data come from 
[L368] your personal observations. Perhaps a friend recently diagnosed with brain can￾cer was a frequent user of cell phones. Is this strong evidence that frequent cell

[L370] Informal observations of this type are called anecdotal evidence. Unfortunately,

[L407] Most countries conduct a regular census. A census attempts to count the

[L619] 4.2 Good and Poor Ways to Sample
[L620] The sample survey is a common type of nonexperimental study. The first step of 
[L621] a sample survey is to define the population targeted by the study. For instance, 
[L622] the Gallup organization (www.gallup.com) conducts a monthly survey of about 
[L623] 1000 adult Americans. Gallup then reports the percentage of those sampled who 
[L624] respond “approve” when asked, “Do you approve or disapprove of the way [the 
[L625] current president of the United States] is handling his job as president?” If the 
[L626] sampling is conducted properly, this provides a good estimate of the approval 
[L627] rate within the entire population. The population consists of all adults living in 
[L628] the United States.
[L629] Sampling Frame and Sampling Design
[L630] Once you’ve identified the population, the second step is to compile a list of sub￾jects so you can sample from it. This list is called the sampling frame.
[L631] Sampling Frame
[L632] The sampling frame is the list of subjects in the population from which the sample is 
[L633] taken.
[L634] Ideally, the sampling frame lists the entire population of interest. In practice, 
[L635] as in a census, it’s usually hard to identify every subject in the population.
[L636] Suppose you plan to sample students at your school, asking students to com￾plete a questionnaire about various issues. The population is all students at the 
[L637] school. One possible sampling frame is the student directory. Another one is a list 
[L638] of registered students.
[L639] Once you have a sampling frame, you need to specify a method for selecting 
[L640] subjects from it. The method used is called the sampling design. Here’s one possi￾ble sampling design for sampling students at your school: You select all students 
[L641] in your statistics class. Do you think your class is necessarily reflective of the 
[L642] entire student body? Do you have a representative mixture of freshmen through 
[L643] seniors, males and females, athletes and nonathletes, working and nonworking 
[L644] students, political party affiliations, and so on? With this sampling design, it’s 
[L645] doubtful.
[L646] When you pick a sample merely by convenience, the results may not be rep￾resentative of the population. Some response outcomes may occur much more 
[L647] frequently than in the population, and some may occur much less. Consider a 
[L648] survey question about the number of hours a week that you work at an outside 
[L649] job. If your class is primarily juniors and seniors, they may be more likely to work 
[L650] than freshmen or sophomores. The mean response in the sample may be much 
[L651] larger than in the overall student population. Information from the sample may 
[L652] be misleading.

[L655] Simple Random Sampling
[L656] You’re more likely to obtain a representative sample if you let chance, rather than 
[L657] convenience, determine the sample. The sampling design should give each student 
[L658] an equal chance to be in the sample. It should also enable the data analyst to figure 
[L659] out how likely it is that descriptive statistics (such as sample means) fall close to 
[L660] corresponding values you’d like to make inferences about for the entire popula￾tion (such as population means). These are reasons for using random sampling.
[L661] You may have been part of a selection process in which your name was put in 
[L662] a box or hat along with many other names, and someone blindly picked a name 
[L663] for a prize. If the names were thoroughly mixed before the selection, this emu￾lates a random type of sampling called a simple random sample. 
[L664] Simple Random Sample
[L665] A simple random sample of n subjects from a population is one in which each possible 
[L666] sample of that size has the same chance of being selected.

[L792] Personal interview In a personal (face-to-face) interview, an interviewer asks 
[L793] prepared questions and records the subject’s responses. An advantage is that 
[L794] subjects are more likely to participate. A disadvantage is the cost. Also, some sub￾jects may not answer sensitive questions pertaining to opinions or lifestyle, such 
[L795] as alcohol and drug use, whether they have been victims of sexual abuse, or their 
[L796] HIV status that they might answer on a printed questionnaire.
[L797] Telephone interview A telephone interview is like a personal interview but 
[L798] conducted over the phone. A main advantage is lower cost because no travel is 
[L799] involved. A disadvantage is that the interview might have to be short. Subjects 
[L800] generally aren’t as patient on the phone and may hang up before starting or com￾pleting the interview.
[L801] Self-administered questionnaire Subjects are requested to fill out a questionnaire 
[L802] mailed, e-mailed, or otherwise available online. An advantage is that it is cheaper 
[L803] than a personal interview. A disadvantage is that fewer people tend to participate.
[L804] So which method is most used? Most major national polls that survey regularly 
[L805] to measure public opinion use the telephone interview. An example is the polls 
[L806] conducted by the Gallup organization. The General Social Survey is an exception, 
[L807] using personal interviews for its questionnaire, which is quite long.
[L808] For telephone interviews, since the mid-1980s, many sample surveys have used 
[L809] random digit dialing to select households. The survey can then obtain a sample 
[L810] without having a sampling frame. In the United States, typically the area code 
[L811] and the 3-digit exchange are randomly selected from the list of all such codes and 
[L812] exchanges. Then, the last four digits are dialed randomly, and an adult is selected 
[L813] randomly within the household. Although this sampling design incorporates 
[L814] randomness, it is not a simple random sample because each sample is not equally 
[L815] likely to be chosen. (Do you see why not? Does everyone have a telephone, or 
[L816] exactly one telephone?)
[L817] Sources of Potential Bias in Sample Surveys
[L818] A variety of problems can cause responses from a sample to favor some parts of 
[L819] the population over others. Then, results from the sample are not representative 
[L820] of the population and are said to exhibit bias.

[L835] Sampling bias Bias may result from the sampling method. The main way 
[L836] this occurs is if the sample is not random. Another way it can occur is due to 
[L837] undercoverage—having a sampling frame that lacks representation from parts of 
[L838] the population. A phone survey using landlines will not reach homeless people, 
[L839] prison inmates, or people who don’t have landline phones. If its sampling frame 
[L840] consists of the names in a phone directory, it will not reach those who don’t have 
[L841] landlines. Most major polling agencies use randomized dialing. Responses by 
[L842] those who are not in the sampling frame might be quite different from those who 
[L843] are in the frame. Bias resulting from the sampling method, such as nonrandom 
[L844] sampling or undercoverage, is called sampling bias.
[L845] Nonresponse bias A second type of bias occurs when some sampled subjects 
[L846] cannot be reached or refuse to participate. This is called nonresponse bias. The 
[L847] subjects who are willing to participate may be different from the overall sample 
[L848] in some systematic way, perhaps having strong emotional convictions about the 
[L849] issues being surveyed. Even those who do participate may not respond to some 
[L850] questions, resulting in nonresponse bias due to missing data. All major surveys 
[L851] suffer from some nonresponse bias. The General Social Survey has a nonre￾sponse rate of about 20–30%. The nonresponse rate is much higher for many 
[L852] telephone surveys. By contrast, government-conducted surveys often have lower 
[L853] nonresponse rates. The Current Population Survey has a nonresponse rate of 
[L854] only about 7%. To reduce nonresponse bias, investigators try to make follow-up 
[L855] contact with the subjects who do not return questionnaires.
[L856] Results have dubious worth when there is substantial nonresponse. For instance, 
[L857] in her best-selling and controversial book Women and Love (1987), author and 
[L858] feminist Shere Hite presented results of a survey of adult women in the United 
[L859] States. One of her conclusions was that 70% of women who had been married at 
[L860] least five years have extramarital affairs. She based this conclusion on responses to 
[L861] questionnaires returned from a sample of 4500 women. This sounds impressively 
[L862] large. However, the questionnaire was mailed to about 100,000 women. We cannot 
[L863] know whether this sample of 4.5% of the women who responded is representative 
[L864] of the 100,000 who received the questionnaire, much less the entire population of 
[L865] adult American women. In fact, Hite was criticized for her research methodology 
[L866] of using a nonrandom sample and the large nonresponse rate.
[L867] Response bias A third type of potential bias is in the actual responses made. 
[L868] This is called response bias. An interviewer might ask the questions in a leading 
[L869] way, such that subjects are more likely to respond a certain way. Or, subjects may 
[L870] lie because they think their response is socially unacceptable, or they may give 
[L871] the response that they think the interviewer prefers.
[L872] If you design an interview or questionnaire, you should strive to construct 
[L873] questions that are clear and understandable. Avoid questions that are confusing, 
[L874] long, or leading. The wording of a question can greatly affect the responses. A 
[L875] Roper poll was designed to determine the percentage of Americans who ex￾press some doubt that the Holocaust occurred in World War II. In response to 
[L876] the question, “Does it seem possible or does it seem impossible to you that the 
[L877] Nazi extermination of the Jews never happened?” 22% said it was possible the 
[L878] Holocaust never happened. The Roper organization later admitted that the ques￾tion was worded in a confusing manner. When it asked, “Does it seem possible 
[L879] to you that the Nazi extermination of the Jews never happened, or do you feel 
[L880] certain that it happened?” only 1% said it was possible it never happened.4

[L923] SUMMARY: Types of Bias in Sample Surveys
[L924] j Sampling bias occurs from using nonrandom samples or having undercoverage.
[L925] j Nonresponse bias occurs when some sampled subjects cannot be reached or 
[L926] refuse to participate or fail to answer some questions.
[L927] j Response bias occurs when the subject gives an incorrect response (perhaps lying) 
[L928] or the way the interviewer asks the questions (or wording of a question in print) is 
[L929] confusing or misleading.
[L930] Poor Ways to Sample
[L931] How the sample is obtained can also result in bias. Two sampling methods that may 
[L932] be necessary but are not ideal are a convenience sample and a volunteer sample.
[L933] Convenience samples Have you ever been stopped on the street or at a shop￾ping mall to participate in a survey? Such a survey is likely not a random sample 
[L934] but rather a convenience sample. It is easy for the interviewer to obtain data 
[L935] relatively cheaply. But the sample may poorly represent the population. Biases 
[L936] may result because of the time and location of the interview and the judgment 
[L937] of the interviewer about whom to interview. For example, working people might 
[L938] be underrepresented if the interviews are conducted on workdays between 9 a.m. 
[L939] and 5 p.m. Poor people may be underrepresented if the interviewer conducts 
[L940] interviews at an upscale shopping mall. Homosexuals might not be selected in a 
[L941] study about romantic relationships if the interviewer is homophobic.
[L942] Volunteer samples Have you ever answered a survey you’ve seen posted on 
[L943] the Internet, such as at the home page for a news organization? A sample of this 
[L944] type, called a volunteer sample, is the most common type of convenience sample. 
[L945] As the name implies, subjects volunteer to be in the sample. One segment of the 
[L946] population may be more likely to volunteer than other segments because they 
[L947] have stronger opinions about the issue or are more likely to visit that Internet 
[L948] site. This results in sampling bias. For instance, a survey by the Pew Research 
[L949] Center (January 6, 2003) estimated that 46% of Republicans said they like to 
[L950] register their opinions in online surveys, compared with only 28% of Democrats. 
[L951] (Why? One possible lurking variable is time spent on the Internet. Perhaps 
[L952] Republicans spend more time on the Internet than Democrats do.) Thus, results 
[L953] of online surveys may be more weighted in the direction of Republicans’ beliefs 
[L954] than the general population.
[L955] Convenience samples are not ideal. Sometimes, however, they are necessary, 
[L956] both in observational studies and in experiments. This is often true in medical 
[L957] studies. Suppose we want to investigate how well a new drug performs compared 
[L958] to a standard drug for subjects who suffer from high blood pressure. We won’t 
[L959] find a sampling frame of all who suffer from high blood pressure and take a sim￾ple random sample of them. We may, however, be able to sample such subjects at 
[L960] medical centers or by using volunteers. Even then, randomization should be used 
[L961] wherever possible. For the study patients, we can randomly select who is given 
[L962] the new drug and who is given the standard one.
[L963] Some samples are poor not only because of their convenience but also be￾cause they use a sampling frame that does not reflect the population. An exam￾ple of this was a poll in 1936 to predict the result of a presidential election.

[L1220] 4.3 Good and Poor Ways to Experiment
[L1221] Just as there are good and poor ways to gather a sample in an observational sur￾vey, there are good and poor ways to conduct an experiment. First, let’s recall the 
[L1222] definition of an experimental study from Section 4.1: We assign each subject to an 
[L1223] experimental condition, called a treatment. We then observe the outcome on the 
[L1224] response variable. The goal of the experiment is to investigate the association—
[L1225] how the treatment affects the response. An advantage of an experimental study 
[L1226] over a nonexperimental study is that it provides stronger evidence for causation.
[L1227] In an experiment, subjects are often referred to as experimental units. This 
[L1228] name emphasizes that the objects measured need not be human beings. They 
[L1229] could, for example, be schools, stores, mice, or computer chips.
[L1230] The Elements of a Good Experiment
[L1231] Let’s consider another example to help us learn what makes a good experiment. 
[L1232] It is common knowledge that smoking is a difficult habit to break. Studies have 
[L1233] reported that regardless of what smokers do to quit, most relapse within a year. 
[L1234] Some scientists have suggested that smokers are less likely to relapse if they take 
[L1235] an antidepressant regularly after they quit. How can you design an experiment to 
[L1236] study whether antidepressants help smokers to quit?
[L1237] For this type of study, as in most medical experiments, it is not feasible to ran￾domly sample the population (all smokers who would like to quit) because they 
[L1238] cannot be readily identified. We need to use a convenience sample. For instance, 
[L1239] a medical center might advertise to attract volunteers from the smokers who 
[L1240] would like to quit.
[L1241] Control comparison group Suppose you have 400 volunteers who would like to 
[L1242] quit smoking. You could ask them to quit, starting today. You could have each start 
[L1243] taking an antidepressant and then a year from now check how many have relapsed. 
[L1244] Perhaps 42% of them would relapse. But this is not enough information.8
[L1245]  You need 
[L1246] to be able to compare this result to the percentage who would relapse if they were 
[L1247] not taking the antidepressant.
[L1248] 8
[L1249] Chapter 12 explains another reason a control group is needed. The regression effect implies that, 
[L1250] over time, poor subjects tend to improve and good subjects tend to get worse, in relative terms.

[L1252] Section 4.3 Good and Poor Ways to Experiment 199
[L1253] An experiment normally has a primary treatment of interest, such as receiving 
[L1254] an antidepressant. But it should also have a second treatment for comparison to 
[L1255] help you analyze the effectiveness of the primary treatment. So the volunteers 
[L1256] should be split into two groups: One group receives the antidepressant, and the 
[L1257] other group does not. You could give the second group a pill that looks like the 
[L1258] antidepressant but that does not have any active ingredient—a placebo. This 
[L1259] second group, using the placebo treatment, is called the control group. After sub￾jects are assigned to the treatments and observed for a certain period of time, the 
[L1260] relapse rates are compared. Because the only distinction between the groups, at 
[L1261] least by design, is taking the antidepressant, the difference between the relapse 
[L1262] rate of two groups is attributed to the treatment.
[L1263] Why bother to give the placebo to the control group if the pill doesn’t contain 
[L1264] any active ingredient? This is partly so that the two treatments appear identical 
[L1265] to the subjects. (As we’ll discuss, subjects should not know which treatment they 
[L1266] are receiving.) This is also because people who take a placebo tend to respond 
[L1267] better than those who receive nothing, perhaps for psychological reasons. This 
[L1268] is called the placebo effect. For instance, of the subjects not receiving the an￾tidepressant, perhaps 75% would relapse within a year, but if they received a 
[L1269] placebo pill perhaps 55% of them would relapse. If the relapse rate was 42% for 
[L1270] subjects who received antidepressants, then in comparing relapse rates for the 
[L1271] antidepressant and control groups, it makes a big difference how you define the 
[L1272] control group. Using these numbers, you would say the reduction in relapse was 
[L1273] 33% (75% − 42%) when comparing it to nothing, but 13% (55% − 42%) when 
[L1274] compared to the placebo group.
[L1275] In some experiments, a control group may receive an existing treatment rather 
[L1276] than a placebo. For instance, a smoking cessation study might analyze whether 
[L1277] an antidepressant works better than a nicotine patch in helping smokers to quit. 
[L1278] It may be unethical not to provide the standard of care, in this case a nicotine 
[L1279] patch, if it has already been shown in previous studies to be more effective than 
[L1280] a placebo. Or the experiment could compare all three treatments: antidepressant, 
[L1281] nicotine patch, and a placebo.
[L1282] Randomization In the smoking cessation experiment, how should the 400 study 
[L1283] subjects be assigned to the treatment groups? Should you personally decide which 
[L1284] treatment each subject receives? This could result in bias. If you are conducting 
[L1285] the study to show that the antidepressant is effective, you might consciously or 
[L1286] subconsciously place smokers you believe will be more likely to succeed into the 
[L1287] group that receives the antidepressant.
[L1288] It is better to use randomization to assign the subjects: Randomly assign 200 of 
[L1289] the 400 subjects to receive the antidepressant and the other 200 subjects to form the 
[L1290] control group. Randomization helps to prevent bias from one treatment group tend￾ing to be different from the other in some way, such as having better health or being 
[L1291] younger. In using randomization, we attempt to balance the treatment groups by 
[L1292] making them similar with respect to their distribution on potential lurking variables. 
[L1293] This enables us to attribute any difference in their relapse rates to the treatments 
[L1294] they are using, not to lurking variables or to researcher bias.
[L1295] You might think you can do better than randomization by using your own 
[L1296] judgment to assign subjects to the treatment groups. For instance, when you iden￾tify a potential lurking variable, you could try to balance the groups according 
[L1297] to its values. If age is that variable, every time you put someone of a particular 
[L1298] age in one treatment group, you could put someone of the same age in the other 
[L1299] treatment group. There are two problems with this: (1) many variables are likely 
[L1300] to be important, and it is difficult to balance groups on all of them at once, and 
[L1301] (2) you may not have thought of other relevant lurking variables. Even if you can 
[L1302] balance the groups on the variables you identified, the groups could be unbal￾anced on these other variables, causing the overall results to be biased in favor of 
[L1303] one treatment.

[L1306] You can feel more confident about the worthiness of new research findings if 
[L1307] they come from a randomized experiment with a control group rather than from 
[L1308] an experiment without a control group, from an experiment that did not use ran￾domization to assign subjects to the treatments, or from an observational study.

[L1310]  of published medical studies about treatments for heart attacks

[L1312] in studies without randomization and control groups but only 9% of the time in 
[L1313] studies having randomization and control groups. This suggests that studies con￾ducted without randomization or without other ways to reduce bias may produce 
[L1314] results that tend to be overly optimistic.
