### Gathering Data (preamble synopsis)

- **Study design and data quality determine whether your conclusions are meaningful.** The chapter frames this as “Garbage in, garbage out”: poor-quality data can compromise both description and inference. **Example:** If your “study-app usage” is logged incorrectly for half the students, even a perfect analysis can’t rescue the conclusion. fileciteturn8file0L3-L21  
- **The goal is to learn when to trust (or doubt) study conclusions by understanding how data were gathered.** The text explicitly contrasts “merely observing” vs “conducting an experiment,” and emphasizes skepticism when design is weak. **Example:** If you only compare app-users vs non-users from a voluntary survey, you should already suspect selection effects. fileciteturn8file0L105-L113  

(Throughout the bullets below I’ll use one running example: **Does a new study app improve Calculus final-exam scores?**)

---

## 4.1 Experimental and Observational Studies

- **Population vs sample (why sampling is used).** Studies typically can’t measure everyone in the population, so they use samples. **Example:** Population = all Calculus students at the university; sample = the 300 students you actually measure. fileciteturn8file0L133-L140  
- **Response variable vs explanatory variable.** The **response variable** is the outcome you care about; the **explanatory variable** is what might influence it. **Example:** Response = exam score; explanatory = app use (yes/no, or hours). fileciteturn8file0L137-L140  
- **Experimental study (experiment) and “treatments.”** An experiment **assigns** subjects to experimental conditions (“treatments”) and observes the response. **Example:** Randomly assign students to “study app” vs “no app,” then compare exam scores. fileciteturn8file0L141-L160  
- **Observational study (nonexperimental).** An observational study measures response/explanatory variables **without imposing** treatments. **Example:** Survey students at the end of term: who used the app and what score they got. fileciteturn8file0L169-L176  
- **Causation: experiments are stronger; observational studies can’t establish cause definitively.** Observational associations may be driven by **lurking variables** (unmeasured variables that distort the relationship). The text explicitly reminds: **association does not imply causation**. **Example:** App-users may already be more conscientious; conscientiousness (lurking variable) could explain higher scores. fileciteturn8file0L293-L305  
- **Why random assignment helps (balancing lurking variables).** Randomly assigning treatments aims to create groups with similar distributions on other factors, reducing the role of lurking variables. **Example:** Random assignment makes it less likely that “highly motivated students” all end up in the app group. fileciteturn8file0L273-L287  
- **Why experiments aren’t always feasible (ethics, compliance, time).** Long-term harmful exposures may be unethical; enforcing treatment adherence can be impractical; and waiting decades is unrealistic—so researchers often resort to observational studies. **Example:** You can’t ethically force one group of students to “never study” for years to test whether studying causes better outcomes. fileciteturn8file0L330-L359  
- **Anecdotal evidence is not reliable evidence about a population.** Personal stories aren’t guaranteed representative (“The plural of anecdote is not data.”). **Example:** “My friend used the app and aced the exam” is not strong evidence the app works for most students. fileciteturn8file0L364-L377  
- **Sample surveys vs censuses.** A **sample survey** takes a sample and collects data (still nonexperimental); a **census** tries to measure everyone, but is often impractical in reality. **Example:** Survey 1,000 students (sample survey) vs forcing all 20,000 students to respond (census-like). fileciteturn8file0L402-L410  

---

## 4.2 Good and Poor Ways to Sample

- **Start by defining the population.** The first step of a survey is to specify exactly who the results should describe. **Example:** “All students enrolled in Calculus I this semester” (not “students who happen to be in the library”). fileciteturn8file0L620-L628  
- **Sampling frame vs sampling design.** The **sampling frame** is the list you sample from; the **sampling design** is how you pick people from that list. A poor design (like selecting your own class) can be unrepresentative. **Example:** Frame = registrar’s roster of Calculus I students; bad design = sample only your tutorial section. fileciteturn8file0L629-L652  
- **Simple random sample (gold standard baseline).** A **simple random sample of size n** means every possible sample of size n has the same chance of selection. **Example:** Randomly select 300 student IDs from the roster using a random-number generator. fileciteturn8file0L655-L666  
- **How random sampling is implemented.** Number the sampling frame, generate random numbers, and select corresponding subjects. **Example:** Label students 1…5000; generate 300 unique random integers; pick those students. fileciteturn8file0L702-L707  

### Key pitfalls (biases) in sampling

- **Sampling bias (including undercoverage).** Happens when the sampling method is nonrandom or the sampling frame misses parts of the population. **Example:** If you sample only students with campus housing emails, you under-cover commuters and may bias results. fileciteturn8file0L835-L844  
- **Nonresponse bias.** Occurs when selected subjects can’t be reached or refuse; responders may systematically differ. **Example:** If only highly engaged students respond to your survey, you may overestimate app effectiveness. fileciteturn8file0L845-L855  
- **Response bias (question wording / dishonesty / interviewer effects).** Responses can be distorted by confusing/leading questions or social desirability. **Example:** Asking “Do you responsibly use the app every day?” will likely inflate “yes” responses compared with a neutral wording. fileciteturn8file0L867-L880  
- **Convenience samples and volunteer samples are risky.** Convenience samples are “easy to get” but often unrepresentative; volunteer samples (common online) can be especially biased. **Example:** An online poll on the app’s homepage will over-sample app enthusiasts. fileciteturn8file0L930-L954  
- **Large sample size does NOT fix biased sampling.** A huge sample can still be wrong if it’s systematically unrepresentative; the Literary Digest poll is used to illustrate this. **Example:** Surveying 10,000 library regulars about grades still biases upward compared with a smaller true random sample of 500 students. fileciteturn8file0L1011-L1023  
- **Summary “good survey” checklist.** Identify population, define sampling frame, use random sampling via random numbers, and remain alert to sampling/response/nonresponse bias. **Example:** A clean design: roster-based random sample + neutral wording + follow-up reminders for nonresponders. fileciteturn8file0L1024-L1032  

---

## 4.3 Good and Poor Ways to Experiment

- **Core experiment logic.** Assign treatments, observe response, study how treatment affects response; experiments give stronger evidence for causation than nonexperimental studies. **Example:** Assign app vs no-app, then compare exam scores. fileciteturn8file0L1220-L1226  
- **“Experimental units.”** The objects receiving treatments (often people, but not necessarily). **Example:** Units could be students, entire tutorial groups, or even schools. fileciteturn8file0L1227-L1229  
- **Control group is essential.** You need a comparison condition to interpret outcomes. **Example:** Without a no-app control group, you can’t tell whether high scores are just the usual performance that term. fileciteturn8file0L1253-L1262  
- **Placebo and the placebo effect.** A **placebo** is an inactive look-alike treatment; people can improve even with placebo (the “placebo effect”), so what you use as control matters. **Example:** Give the control group a “sham app” (same interface, no study features) to separate “expectation effects” from real app effects. fileciteturn8file0L1257-L1274  
- **Randomization in assignment prevents bias and balances lurking variables.** Random assignment reduces the chance that groups differ systematically (e.g., health/age/motivation). **Example:** Randomly assign students rather than letting keen students choose the app group. fileciteturn8file0L1282-L1293  
- **Why “I’ll balance groups by judgment” is unreliable.** You can’t reliably balance on all relevant variables, and you may miss key lurking variables. **Example:** Even if you match on prior grade, you might miss differences in time available to study. fileciteturn8file0L1295-L1303  
- **Well-controlled randomized experiments are less prone to “overly optimistic” results.** The text notes comparisons where weakly controlled studies report benefits much more often than well-controlled ones. **Example:** If you don’t randomize, you might “discover” benefits that disappear under proper random assignment. fileciteturn8file0L1306-L1314  
- **Blinding (especially double-blind) reduces biased handling/measurement.** **Double-blind** means neither participants nor people interacting with/assessing them know treatment assignment. **Example:** Students might not be fully blind in education studies, but graders can be blinded to who used the app to avoid leniency bias. fileciteturn8file0L1323-L1331  
- **Generalizability warning for convenience samples.** Experiments often use volunteers; conclusions may not generalize broadly if the sample is unrepresentative. **Example:** If only highly motivated volunteers join the app trial, you should be cautious about claiming the app helps all students. fileciteturn8file0L1347-L1351  
- **What “good experiment” means here (summary).** Control comparison group, randomization, blinding, and replication to build confidence. **Example:** Run the app trial again next semester to see if results replicate. fileciteturn8file0L1416-L1427  

---

## 4.4 Other Ways to Conduct Experimental and Nonexperimental Studies

- **Why this section exists: real studies often use stronger variants of “simple random sample” and “simple experiment.”** It introduces practical sampling designs, observational designs for questions where experiments aren’t feasible, and experiments with multiple explanatory variables. **Example:** One study can test both “app use” and “tutoring” at once. fileciteturn8file0L1583-L1589  

### Sample surveys: beyond simple random sampling

- **Cluster random sampling.** Randomly select clusters (preexisting groups) and include subjects within selected clusters; useful when a complete sampling frame is hard or costly. **Example:** Randomly select 10 Calculus tutorial groups (clusters) and survey all students in those groups. fileciteturn8file0L1596-L1609  
  - **Tradeoff:** cheaper/easier logistics, but can require larger sample sizes and can be less diverse if few clusters are chosen. **Example:** If you pick only morning tutorials, you may accidentally miss patterns in evening students. fileciteturn8file0L1613-L1621  
- **Stratified random sampling.** Split population into strata (subgroups) and sample randomly within each stratum; helps ensure enough data in each subgroup. **Example:** Sample 50 students from each year level (freshman/sophomore/junior/senior) to compare app effects across years. fileciteturn8file0L1624-L1636  
  - **Tradeoff:** needs stratum info for everyone in the sampling frame. **Example:** If you don’t know who is a working student in your roster, you can’t stratify on “has job.” fileciteturn8file0L1637-L1641  
- **Cluster vs stratified (conceptual difference).** Stratified uses *all* strata and samples within each; cluster samples *some* clusters and takes everyone (or many) inside selected clusters. **Example:** Stratify by major and sample within each major vs cluster by tutorial group and include whole selected groups. fileciteturn8file0L1649-L1653  
- **Multi-stage designs are common in large surveys.** Combine stages (e.g., sample clusters, then sample within them). **Example:** Randomly select tutorial groups, then randomly sample 15 students within each selected group. fileciteturn8file0L1662-L1673  

### Observational studies: designs that go beyond “one-time survey”

- **Retrospective vs prospective observational studies.** Retrospective looks backward; prospective follows subjects forward. **Example:** Retrospective: after finals, look back at app usage; prospective: enroll students at semester start and track app usage and later exam scores. fileciteturn8file0L1717-L1719  
- **Case-control study (a key retrospective design).** Compare “cases” (have outcome) vs “controls” (don’t) on an explanatory variable; common when experiments are impractical/unethical. **Example:** Cases = students who failed; controls = students who passed; compare how often they used the app. fileciteturn8file0L1762-L1766  
  - **Important limitation:** because the numbers of cases/controls are fixed by design, you generally can’t estimate population prevalence from the case-control sample itself. **Example:** If you deliberately sample 50 failers and 50 passers, you can’t conclude “50% of students fail.” fileciteturn8file0L1772-L1780  
- **Matching in case-control studies reduces lurking-variable distortion.** When randomization isn’t possible, matching cases/controls on key variables is an attempt to achieve balance. **Example:** Match failing students to passing students with similar prior GPA and similar course section before comparing app usage. fileciteturn8file0L1808-L1813  
- **Causation and observational evidence: still not definitive, but confidence can build across many studies.** The text emphasizes you can’t prove causation definitively via observational data, but consistent evidence across diverse studies (and adjustment for confounding variables) can make alternative explanations less plausible. **Example:** If multiple cohorts and case-control studies, across universities, keep finding app use predicts higher scores even after controlling for motivation proxies, confidence increases. fileciteturn8file0L1847-L1865  

### Experiments: richer designs than “one factor, two groups”

- **Factors and multifactor experiments.** A **factor** is a categorical explanatory variable; multifactor experiments study two or more factors simultaneously via combined treatment groups. **Example:** Factor A = app vs no app; Factor B = tutoring vs no tutoring → 4 treatment groups (app+tutoring, app-only, tutoring-only, neither). fileciteturn8file0L1866-L1901  
- **Matched pairs and crossover designs.** Matched pairs compare two treatments within the same unit; a **crossover design** is matched pairs where subjects switch treatments over time. This reduces confounding because each subject serves as their own control. **Example:** Each student uses the app for Unit 1 and the sham app for Unit 2, with the order randomized. fileciteturn8file0L1990-L2002  
- **Blocking and randomized block designs.** A **block** is a set of similar experimental units; you randomize treatments *within* blocks to compare on a more level playing field. **Example:** Block students by prior GPA band (low/medium/high), then randomize app vs no-app within each band. fileciteturn8file0L2013-L2017  
- **Randomize within blocks / watch for carry-over effects in crossover studies.** Order can bias results if earlier treatment affects later outcomes (carry-over). **Example:** If the app teaches lasting study habits, using it first could boost performance even in the later “no app” phase—so randomize the order and/or add a washout period. fileciteturn8file0L2018-L2023

[L9] Let’s consider another example to help us learn what makes a good experiment.

[L36] relapse rates are compared. Because the only distinction between the groups, at

[L5] but rather a convenience sample. It is easy for the interviewer to obtain data 
[L6] relatively cheaply. But the sample may poorly represent the population. Biases

[L10] and 5 p.m. Poor people may be underrepresented if the interviewer conducts 
[L11] interviews at an upscale shopping mall. Homosexuals might not be selected in a 
[L12] study about romantic relationships if the interviewer is homophobic.
[L13] Volunteer samples Have you ever answered a survey you’ve seen posted on 
[L14] the Internet, such as at the home page for a news organization? A sample of this 
[L15] type, called a volunteer sample, is the most common type of convenience sample. 
[L16] As the name implies, subjects volunteer to be in the sample. One segment of the 
[L17] population may be more likely to volunteer than other segments because they 
[L18] have stronger opinions about the issue or are more likely to visit that Internet

[L47] A matched-pairs design in which subjects cross over during the experiment 
[L48] from using one treatment to using another treatment is called a crossover design. 
[L49] Crossover design helps remove certain sources of potential bias. Using the same 
[L50] subjects for each treatment keeps potential lurking variables from affecting the <PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 35 / 45>Section 4.4 Other Ways to Conduct Experimental and Nonexperimental Studies 213
[L51] results because those variables take the same values for each treatment. For in￾stance, any difference observed between the drug and the placebo responses is 
[L52] not because subjects taking the drug had better overall health. Another example 
[L53] of a matched pair, crossover design is Study 3 discussed in Example 1.
[L54] An additional application of a matched-pairs design occurs in agricultural ex￾periments that compare the crop yield for two fertilizer types. In each field, two 
[L55] plots are marked, one for each fertilizer. Two plots in the same field are likely to 
[L56] be more similar in soil quality and moisture than two plots from different fields. 
[L57] If we instead used a completely randomized design to assign entire fields to each 
[L58] fertilizer treatment, there’s the possibility that by chance one fertilizer will be 
[L59] applied to fields that have better soil. This is especially true when the experiment 
[L60] can’t use many fields.
[L61] Blocking in an Experiment
[L62] The matched-pairs design extends to the comparison of more than two treat￾ments.

[L5] 4.4 Other Ways to Conduct Experimental 
[L6] and Nonexperimental Studies
[L7] In this chapter, we’ve learned the basics of ways to conduct nonexperimental 
[L8] and experimental studies. This final section shows ways these methods are often 
[L9] extended in practice so they are even more powerful. We’ll first learn about 
[L10] alternatives to simple random sampling in sample surveys and then about types 
[L11] of observational studies that enable us to study questions for which experiments 
[L12] with humans are not feasible. Finally, we’ll learn how to study the effects of two 
[L13] or more explanatory variables with a single experiment.
[L14] Sample Surveys: Other Random Sampling 
[L15] Designs Useful in Practice
[L16] Simple random sampling gives every possible sample the same chance of selection. 
[L17] In practice, more complex random sampling designs are often easier to implement 
[L18] or are more efficient, requiring a smaller sampling size for the same precision. 
[L19] Sometimes they are even preferable to simple random sampling.
[L20] Cluster random sampling To use simple random sampling, we need a sampling 
[L21] frame—the list of all, or nearly all, subjects in the population. In some cases, this 
[L22] information is not available. It may be easier to identify clusters of subjects. A 
[L23] study of residents of a country can identify counties or census tracts. A study of 
[L24] students can identify schools. A study of the elderly living in institutions can iden￾tify nursing homes. We can obtain a sample by randomly selecting the clusters and 
[L25] observing each subject in the clusters chosen.
[L26] For instance, suppose you would like to sample about 1% of the families in 
[L27] your city. You could use city blocks as clusters. Using a map to label and number 
[L28] city blocks, you could select a simple random sample of 1% of the blocks and 
[L29] then select every family on each of those blocks for your observations.
[L30] Cluster Random Sample
[L31] Divide the population into a large number of clusters, such as city blocks. Select a simple 
[L32] random sample of the clusters. Use the subjects in those clusters as the sample. This is a 
[L33] cluster random sample.
[L34] For personal interviews, when the subjects within a cluster are close geograph￾ically, cluster sampling is less expensive per observation than simple random 
[L35] sampling. By interviewing every family in a particular city block, you can obtain 
[L36] many observations quickly and with little travel.
[L37] SUMMARY: Advantages and Disadvantages of a Cluster 
[L38] Random Sample
[L39] Cluster random sampling is a preferable sampling design if
[L40] j A reliable sampling frame is not available, or
[L41] j The cost of selecting a simple random sample is excessive.
[L42] The disadvantages are:
[L43] j We usually require a larger sample size with cluster sampling for the same level 
[L44] of precision.
[L45] j Selecting a small number of clusters might result in a sample that is more homoge￾neous than the population.<PARSED TEXT FOR PAGE: 27 / 45>Section 4.4 Other Ways to Conduct Experimental and Nonexperimental Studies 205
[L46] Stratified random sampling Suppose we are interested in estimating the mean 
[L47] number of hours a week that students in your school work on outside employ￾ment. The plan is to use the student directory to take a simple random sample of 
[L48] n = 40 students and analyze how the mean compares for freshmen, sophomores, 
[L49] juniors, and seniors. Merely by chance, you may get only a few observations from 
[L50] one of the classes, making it hard to estimate the mean well for that class.

[L132] 4.1 Experimental and Observational Studies
[L133] We use statistics to learn about a population. The German and British studies in

[L141] Types of Studies: Experimental and Observational
[L142] Some studies, such as Study 3 in Example 1, perform an experiment. Subjects are

[L145] called treatments. They correspond to different values of the explanatory variable.

[L259] As we will soon discuss, an experimental study gives the researcher more control 
[L260] over outside influences. This control can allow more accuracy in studying the 
[L261] association.
[L262] Advantage of Experiments Over 
[L263] Observational Studies
[L264] In an observational study, lurking variables can affect the results. Study 1 in 
[L265] Example 1 found an association between cell phone use and eye cancer. However, 
[L266] there could be lifestyle, genetic, or health differences between the subjects with eye 
[L267] cancer and those without it, and between those who use cell phones a lot and those 
[L268] who do not. A lurking variable could affect the observed association. For example, 
[L269] a possible lifestyle lurking variable is computer use. Perhaps those who use cell 
[L270] phones often also use computers frequently. Perhaps high exposure to computer 
[L271] screens increases the chance of eye cancer. In that case, the higher prevalence of 
[L272] eye cancer for heavier users of cell phones could be due to their higher use of com￾puters, not their higher use of cell phones.
[L273] By contrast, an experiment reduces the potential for lurking variables to affect 
[L274] the results. Why? We’ll see that with a type of “random” selection to determine 
[L275] which subjects receive each treatment, we are attempting to form and balance 
[L276] groups of subjects receiving the different treatments; that is, the groups have 
[L277] similar distributions on other variables, such as lifestyle, genetic, or health char￾acteristics. For instance, suppose the researchers in cell phone Study 3 decided 
[L278] to have 24 subjects receive the “on” condition and 23 subjects receive the “off” 
[L279] condition instead of having each subject receive both treatments. The health of 
[L280] the subjects could be a factor in how the brain responds to the treatments and 
[L281] the amount of brain activity that appears on the scans. If we randomly determine 
[L282] which subjects receive the “on” condition and which do not, the two groups of 
[L283] subjects are expected to have similar distributions on health. One group will not 
[L284] be much healthier, on average, than the other group. When the groups are bal￾anced on a lurking variable, there is no association between the lurking variable 
[L285] and the explanatory variable (for instance, between health of the subject and 
[L286] whether the subject receives the “on” condition). Then, the lurking variable will 
[L287] not affect how the explanatory variable is associated with the response variable. 
[L288] One treatment group will not tend to have more brain activity because of health 
[L289] differences, on the average.
[L290] In Study 3, described in Example 1, by using the same subjects for both treat￾ments, the researchers were attempting to further control the variability from the 
[L291] subject’s health. In this experimental study, it was important to randomize the 
[L292] order in which the subject received the treatment.
[L293] Establishing cause and effect is central to science. But it’s not possible to 
[L294] establish cause and effect definitively with observational studies. There’s al￾ways the possibility that some lurking variable could be responsible for the 
[L295] association. If people who make greater use of cell phones have a higher rate of 
[L296] eye cancer, it may be because of some variable that we failed to measure in our 
[L297] study, such as computer use. As we learned in Section 3.4, association does not 
[L298] imply causation.
[L299] Because it’s easier to address the potential impact of lurking variables in an 
[L300] experiment than in an observational study, we can study the effect of an explan￾atory variable on a response variable more accurately with an experiment than 
[L301] with an observational study. With an experiment, the researcher has control over 
[L302] which treatment each subject receives. If we find an association between the 
[L303] explanatory variable and the response variable, we can be more sure that we’ve 
[L304] discovered a causal relationship than if we merely find an association in an ob￾servational study. Consequently, the best method for determining causality is to 
[L305] conduct an experiment.

[L308] a variable not observed in the study that 
[L309] influences the association between the 
[L310] response and explanatory variables due 
[L311] to its own association with each of those 
[L312] variables. b

[L330] Determining Which Type of Study Is Possible
[L331] If experiments are preferable, why ever conduct an observational study? Why 
[L332] bother to measure whether cell phone usage was greater for those with cancer 
[L333] than for those not having it? Why not instead conduct an experiment, such as 
[L334] the following: Pick half the students from your school at random and tell them to 
[L335] use a cell phone each day for the next 50 years. Tell the other half of the student 
[L336] body never to use cell phones. Fifty years from now, analyze whether cancer was 
[L337] more common for those who used cell phones.
[L338] There are obvious difficulties with such an experiment:
[L339] j It’s not ethical for a study to expose over a long period of time some of the 
[L340] subjects to something (such as cell phone radiation) that we suspect may be 
[L341] harmful.
[L342] j It’s difficult in practice to make sure that the subjects behave as told. How can 
[L343] you monitor them to ensure that they adhere to their treatment assignment 
[L344] over the 50-year experimental period?
[L345] j Who wants to wait 50 years to get an answer?
[L346] For these reasons, medical experiments are often performed over a short time 
[L347] period or often with exposure to treatments that would not be out of the ordinary 
[L348] (such as a one-time exposure to cell phone activity). To measure the effects on 
[L349] people of longer exposure to potentially harmful treatments, often the experiment 
[L350] uses animals such as mice instead of people. Because inferences about human 
[L351] populations are more trustworthy when we use samples of human subjects than 
[L352] when we use samples of animal subjects, scientists often resort to observational 
[L353] studies. Then we are not deliberately placing people in harm’s way, but observing 
[L354] people who have chosen on their own to take part in the activity of interest. In 
[L355] today’s information age, a lot of data is readily available to assist (or impede) 
[L356] people from making decisions about the relationship between variables. These 
[L357] data provide only observational comparisons. We’ll study methods for designing a 
[L358] good observational study in Section 4.4. This can yield useful information when an 
[L359] experiment is not practical.
[L360] Finally, another reason nonexperimental studies are common is that many 
[L361] questions of interest do not involve trying to assess causality. For instance, if we 
[L362] want to gauge the public’s opinion on some issue, or if we want to conduct a mar￾keting study to see how people rate a new product, it’s completely adequate to 
[L363] use a study that samples (appropriately) the population of interest.
[L364] Using Data Already Available
[L365] Of course, you will not conduct a study every time you want to answer some 
[L366] question, such as whether cell phone use is dangerous. It’s human nature to rely 
[L367] instead on already available data. The most readily available data come from 
[L368] your personal observations. Perhaps a friend recently diagnosed with brain can￾cer was a frequent user of cell phones. Is this strong evidence that frequent cell 
[L369] phone use increases the likelihood of getting brain cancer?
[L370] Informal observations of this type are called anecdotal evidence. Unfortunately, 
[L371] there is no way to tell whether they are representative of what happens for an en￾tire population. Sometimes you hear people give anecdotal evidence to attempt to 
[L372] disprove causal relationships. “My Uncle Geoffrey is 85 years old and he’s smoked 
[L373] a pack of cigarettes a day for his entire adult life, yet he’s as healthy as a horse.” An 
[L374] association does not need to be perfect, however, to be causal. Not all people who

[L407] Most countries conduct a regular census. A census attempts to count the

[L619] 4.2 Good and Poor Ways to Sample
[L620] The sample survey is a common type of nonexperimental study. The first step of 
[L621] a sample survey is to define the population targeted by the study. For instance, 
[L622] the Gallup organization (www.gallup.com) conducts a monthly survey of about 
[L623] 1000 adult Americans. Gallup then reports the percentage of those sampled who 
[L624] respond “approve” when asked, “Do you approve or disapprove of the way [the 
[L625] current president of the United States] is handling his job as president?” If the 
[L626] sampling is conducted properly, this provides a good estimate of the approval 
[L627] rate within the entire population. The population consists of all adults living in 
[L628] the United States.
[L629] Sampling Frame and Sampling Design
[L630] Once you’ve identified the population, the second step is to compile a list of sub￾jects so you can sample from it. This list is called the sampling frame.
[L631] Sampling Frame
[L632] The sampling frame is the list of subjects in the population from which the sample is 
[L633] taken.
[L634] Ideally, the sampling frame lists the entire population of interest. In practice, 
[L635] as in a census, it’s usually hard to identify every subject in the population.
[L636] Suppose you plan to sample students at your school, asking students to com￾plete a questionnaire about various issues. The population is all students at the 
[L637] school. One possible sampling frame is the student directory. Another one is a list 
[L638] of registered students.
[L639] Once you have a sampling frame, you need to specify a method for selecting 
[L640] subjects from it. The method used is called the sampling design. Here’s one possi￾ble sampling design for sampling students at your school: You select all students 
[L641] in your statistics class. Do you think your class is necessarily reflective of the 
[L642] entire student body? Do you have a representative mixture of freshmen through 
[L643] seniors, males and females, athletes and nonathletes, working and nonworking 
[L644] students, political party affiliations, and so on? With this sampling design, it’s 
[L645] doubtful.
[L646] When you pick a sample merely by convenience, the results may not be rep￾resentative of the population. Some response outcomes may occur much more 
[L647] frequently than in the population, and some may occur much less. Consider a 
[L648] survey question about the number of hours a week that you work at an outside 
[L649] job. If your class is primarily juniors and seniors, they may be more likely to work 
[L650] than freshmen or sophomores. The mean response in the sample may be much 
[L651] larger than in the overall student population. Information from the sample may 
[L652] be misleading.

[L655] Simple Random Sampling
[L656] You’re more likely to obtain a representative sample if you let chance, rather than 
[L657] convenience, determine the sample. The sampling design should give each student 
[L658] an equal chance to be in the sample. It should also enable the data analyst to figure 
[L659] out how likely it is that descriptive statistics (such as sample means) fall close to 
[L660] corresponding values you’d like to make inferences about for the entire popula￾tion (such as population means). These are reasons for using random sampling.
[L661] You may have been part of a selection process in which your name was put in 
[L662] a box or hat along with many other names, and someone blindly picked a name 
[L663] for a prize. If the names were thoroughly mixed before the selection, this emu￾lates a random type of sampling called a simple random sample. 
[L664] Simple Random Sample
[L665] A simple random sample of n subjects from a population is one in which each possible 
[L666] sample of that size has the same chance of being selected.

[L796] HIV status that they might answer on a printed questionnaire.
[L797] Telephone interview A telephone interview is like a personal interview but 
[L798] conducted over the phone. A main advantage is lower cost because no travel is 
[L799] involved. A disadvantage is that the interview might have to be short. Subjects 
[L800] generally aren’t as patient on the phone and may hang up before starting or com￾pleting the interview.
[L801] Self-administered questionnaire Subjects are requested to fill out a questionnaire 
[L802] mailed, e-mailed, or otherwise available online. An advantage is that it is cheaper 
[L803] than a personal interview. A disadvantage is that fewer people tend to participate.
[L804] So which method is most used? Most major national polls that survey regularly 
[L805] to measure public opinion use the telephone interview. An example is the polls 
[L806] conducted by the Gallup organization. The General Social Survey is an exception, 
[L807] using personal interviews for its questionnaire, which is quite long.
[L808] For telephone interviews, since the mid-1980s, many sample surveys have used 
[L809] random digit dialing to select households. The survey can then obtain a sample 
[L810] without having a sampling frame. In the United States, typically the area code 
[L811] and the 3-digit exchange are randomly selected from the list of all such codes and 
[L812] exchanges. Then, the last four digits are dialed randomly, and an adult is selected 
[L813] randomly within the household. Although this sampling design incorporates 
[L814] randomness, it is not a simple random sample because each sample is not equally 
[L815] likely to be chosen. (Do you see why not? Does everyone have a telephone, or 
[L816] exactly one telephone?)
[L817] Sources of Potential Bias in Sample Surveys
[L818] A variety of problems can cause responses from a sample to favor some parts of 
[L819] the population over others. Then, results from the sample are not representative 
[L820] of the population and are said to exhibit bias.

[L835] Sampling bias Bias may result from the sampling method. The main way 
[L836] this occurs is if the sample is not random. Another way it can occur is due to 
[L837] undercoverage—having a sampling frame that lacks representation from parts of 
[L838] the population. A phone survey using landlines will not reach homeless people, 
[L839] prison inmates, or people who don’t have landline phones. If its sampling frame 
[L840] consists of the names in a phone directory, it will not reach those who don’t have 
[L841] landlines. Most major polling agencies use randomized dialing. Responses by 
[L842] those who are not in the sampling frame might be quite different from those who 
[L843] are in the frame. Bias resulting from the sampling method, such as nonrandom 
[L844] sampling or undercoverage, is called sampling bias.
[L845] Nonresponse bias A second type of bias occurs when some sampled subjects 
[L846] cannot be reached or refuse to participate. This is called nonresponse bias. The 
[L847] subjects who are willing to participate may be different from the overall sample 
[L848] in some systematic way, perhaps having strong emotional convictions about the 
[L849] issues being surveyed. Even those who do participate may not respond to some 
[L850] questions, resulting in nonresponse bias due to missing data. All major surveys 
[L851] suffer from some nonresponse bias. The General Social Survey has a nonre￾sponse rate of about 20–30%. The nonresponse rate is much higher for many 
[L852] telephone surveys. By contrast, government-conducted surveys often have lower 
[L853] nonresponse rates. The Current Population Survey has a nonresponse rate of 
[L854] only about 7%. To reduce nonresponse bias, investigators try to make follow-up 
[L855] contact with the subjects who do not return questionnaires.
[L856] Results have dubious worth when there is substantial nonresponse. For instance, 
[L857] in her best-selling and controversial book Women and Love (1987), author and 
[L858] feminist Shere Hite presented results of a survey of adult women in the United 
[L859] States. One of her conclusions was that 70% of women who had been married at 
[L860] least five years have extramarital affairs. She based this conclusion on responses to 
[L861] questionnaires returned from a sample of 4500 women. This sounds impressively 
[L862] large. However, the questionnaire was mailed to about 100,000 women. We cannot 
[L863] know whether this sample of 4.5% of the women who responded is representative 
[L864] of the 100,000 who received the questionnaire, much less the entire population of 
[L865] adult American women. In fact, Hite was criticized for her research methodology 
[L866] of using a nonrandom sample and the large nonresponse rate.
[L867] Response bias A third type of potential bias is in the actual responses made. 
[L868] This is called response bias. An interviewer might ask the questions in a leading 
[L869] way, such that subjects are more likely to respond a certain way. Or, subjects may 
[L870] lie because they think their response is socially unacceptable, or they may give 
[L871] the response that they think the interviewer prefers.
[L872] If you design an interview or questionnaire, you should strive to construct 
[L873] questions that are clear and understandable. Avoid questions that are confusing, 
[L874] long, or leading. The wording of a question can greatly affect the responses. A 
[L875] Roper poll was designed to determine the percentage of Americans who ex￾press some doubt that the Holocaust occurred in World War II. In response to

[L879] to you that the Nazi extermination of the Jews never happened, or do you feel 
[L880] certain that it happened?” only 1% said it was possible it never happened.4

[L923] SUMMARY: Types of Bias in Sample Surveys
[L924] j Sampling bias occurs from using nonrandom samples or having undercoverage.
[L925] j Nonresponse bias occurs when some sampled subjects cannot be reached or 
[L926] refuse to participate or fail to answer some questions.
[L927] j Response bias occurs when the subject gives an incorrect response (perhaps lying) 
[L928] or the way the interviewer asks the questions (or wording of a question in print) is 
[L929] confusing or misleading.
[L930] Poor Ways to Sample
[L931] How the sample is obtained can also result in bias. Two sampling methods that may 
[L932] be necessary but are not ideal are a convenience sample and a volunteer sample.
[L933] Convenience samples Have you ever been stopped on the street or at a shop￾ping mall to participate in a survey? Such a survey is likely not a random sample 
[L934] but rather a convenience sample. It is easy for the interviewer to obtain data 
[L935] relatively cheaply. But the sample may poorly represent the population. Biases 
[L936] may result because of the time and location of the interview and the judgment 
[L937] of the interviewer about whom to interview. For example, working people might 
[L938] be underrepresented if the interviews are conducted on workdays between 9 a.m. 
[L939] and 5 p.m. Poor people may be underrepresented if the interviewer conducts 
[L940] interviews at an upscale shopping mall. Homosexuals might not be selected in a 
[L941] study about romantic relationships if the interviewer is homophobic.
[L942] Volunteer samples Have you ever answered a survey you’ve seen posted on 
[L943] the Internet, such as at the home page for a news organization? A sample of this 
[L944] type, called a volunteer sample, is the most common type of convenience sample. 
[L945] As the name implies, subjects volunteer to be in the sample. One segment of the 
[L946] population may be more likely to volunteer than other segments because they 
[L947] have stronger opinions about the issue or are more likely to visit that Internet 
[L948] site. This results in sampling bias. For instance, a survey by the Pew Research 
[L949] Center (January 6, 2003) estimated that 46% of Republicans said they like to 
[L950] register their opinions in online surveys, compared with only 28% of Democrats. 
[L951] (Why? One possible lurking variable is time spent on the Internet. Perhaps 
[L952] Republicans spend more time on the Internet than Democrats do.) Thus, results 
[L953] of online surveys may be more weighted in the direction of Republicans’ beliefs 
[L954] than the general population.
[L955] Convenience samples are not ideal. Sometimes, however, they are necessary, 
[L956] both in observational studies and in experiments. This is often true in medical 
[L957] studies. Suppose we want to investigate how well a new drug performs compared 
[L958] to a standard drug for subjects who suffer from high blood pressure. We won’t 
[L959] find a sampling frame of all who suffer from high blood pressure and take a sim￾ple random sample of them. We may, however, be able to sample such subjects at 
[L960] medical centers or by using volunteers. Even then, randomization should be used 
[L961] wherever possible. For the study patients, we can randomly select who is given 
[L962] the new drug and who is given the standard one.
[L963] Some samples are poor not only because of their convenience but also be￾cause they use a sampling frame that does not reflect the population. An exam￾ple of this was a poll in 1936 to predict the result of a presidential election.

[L1220] 4.3 Good and Poor Ways to Experiment
[L1221] Just as there are good and poor ways to gather a sample in an observational sur￾vey, there are good and poor ways to conduct an experiment. First, let’s recall the 
[L1222] definition of an experimental study from Section 4.1: We assign each subject to an 
[L1223] experimental condition, called a treatment. We then observe the outcome on the 
[L1224] response variable. The goal of the experiment is to investigate the association—
[L1225] how the treatment affects the response. An advantage of an experimental study 
[L1226] over a nonexperimental study is that it provides stronger evidence for causation.
[L1227] In an experiment, subjects are often referred to as experimental units. This 
[L1228] name emphasizes that the objects measured need not be human beings. They 
[L1229] could, for example, be schools, stores, mice, or computer chips.
[L1230] The Elements of a Good Experiment
[L1231] Let’s consider another example to help us learn what makes a good experiment. 
[L1232] It is common knowledge that smoking is a difficult habit to break. Studies have 
[L1233] reported that regardless of what smokers do to quit, most relapse within a year. 
[L1234] Some scientists have suggested that smokers are less likely to relapse if they take 
[L1235] an antidepressant regularly after they quit. How can you design an experiment to 
[L1236] study whether antidepressants help smokers to quit?
[L1237] For this type of study, as in most medical experiments, it is not feasible to ran￾domly sample the population (all smokers who would like to quit) because they 
[L1238] cannot be readily identified. We need to use a convenience sample. For instance, 
[L1239] a medical center might advertise to attract volunteers from the smokers who 
[L1240] would like to quit.
[L1241] Control comparison group Suppose you have 400 volunteers who would like to 
[L1242] quit smoking. You could ask them to quit, starting today. You could have each start 
[L1243] taking an antidepressant and then a year from now check how many have relapsed. 
[L1244] Perhaps 42% of them would relapse. But this is not enough information.8
[L1245]  You need 
[L1246] to be able to compare this result to the percentage who would relapse if they were 
[L1247] not taking the antidepressant.
[L1248] 8
[L1249] Chapter 12 explains another reason a control group is needed. The regression effect implies that, 
[L1250] over time, poor subjects tend to improve and good subjects tend to get worse, in relative terms.

[L1252] Section 4.3 Good and Poor Ways to Experiment 199
[L1253] An experiment normally has a primary treatment of interest, such as receiving 
[L1254] an antidepressant. But it should also have a second treatment for comparison to 
[L1255] help you analyze the effectiveness of the primary treatment. So the volunteers 
[L1256] should be split into two groups: One group receives the antidepressant, and the 
[L1257] other group does not. You could give the second group a pill that looks like the 
[L1258] antidepressant but that does not have any active ingredient—a placebo. This 
[L1259] second group, using the placebo treatment, is called the control group. After sub￾jects are assigned to the treatments and observed for a certain period of time, the 
[L1260] relapse rates are compared. Because the only distinction between the groups, at 
[L1261] least by design, is taking the antidepressant, the difference between the relapse 
[L1262] rate of two groups is attributed to the treatment.
[L1263] Why bother to give the placebo to the control group if the pill doesn’t contain 
[L1264] any active ingredient? This is partly so that the two treatments appear identical 
[L1265] to the subjects. (As we’ll discuss, subjects should not know which treatment they 
[L1266] are receiving.) This is also because people who take a placebo tend to respond 
[L1267] better than those who receive nothing, perhaps for psychological reasons. This 
[L1268] is called the placebo effect. For instance, of the subjects not receiving the an￾tidepressant, perhaps 75% would relapse within a year, but if they received a 
[L1269] placebo pill perhaps 55% of them would relapse. If the relapse rate was 42% for 
[L1270] subjects who received antidepressants, then in comparing relapse rates for the 
[L1271] antidepressant and control groups, it makes a big difference how you define the 
[L1272] control group. Using these numbers, you would say the reduction in relapse was 
[L1273] 33% (75% − 42%) when comparing it to nothing, but 13% (55% − 42%) when 
[L1274] compared to the placebo group.
[L1275] In some experiments, a control group may receive an existing treatment rather 
[L1276] than a placebo. For instance, a smoking cessation study might analyze whether 
[L1277] an antidepressant works better than a nicotine patch in helping smokers to quit. 
[L1278] It may be unethical not to provide the standard of care, in this case a nicotine 
[L1279] patch, if it has already been shown in previous studies to be more effective than 
[L1280] a placebo. Or the experiment could compare all three treatments: antidepressant, 
[L1281] nicotine patch, and a placebo.
[L1282] Randomization In the smoking cessation experiment, how should the 400 study 
[L1283] subjects be assigned to the treatment groups? Should you personally decide which 
[L1284] treatment each subject receives? This could result in bias. If you are conducting 
[L1285] the study to show that the antidepressant is effective, you might consciously or 
[L1286] subconsciously place smokers you believe will be more likely to succeed into the 
[L1287] group that receives the antidepressant.
[L1288] It is better to use randomization to assign the subjects: Randomly assign 200 of 
[L1289] the 400 subjects to receive the antidepressant and the other 200 subjects to form the 
[L1290] control group. Randomization helps to prevent bias from one treatment group tend￾ing to be different from the other in some way, such as having better health or being 
[L1291] younger. In using randomization, we attempt to balance the treatment groups by 
[L1292] making them similar with respect to their distribution on potential lurking variables. 
[L1293] This enables us to attribute any difference in their relapse rates to the treatments 
[L1294] they are using, not to lurking variables or to researcher bias.
[L1295] You might think you can do better than randomization by using your own 
[L1296] judgment to assign subjects to the treatment groups. For instance, when you iden￾tify a potential lurking variable, you could try to balance the groups according 
[L1297] to its values. If age is that variable, every time you put someone of a particular 
[L1298] age in one treatment group, you could put someone of the same age in the other 
[L1299] treatment group. There are two problems with this: (1) many variables are likely 
[L1300] to be important, and it is difficult to balance groups on all of them at once, and 
[L1301] (2) you may not have thought of other relevant lurking variables. Even if you can 
[L1302] balance the groups on the variables you identified, the groups could be unbal￾anced on these other variables, causing the overall results to be biased in favor of 
[L1303] one treatment.

[L1306] You can feel more confident about the worthiness of new research findings if 
[L1307] they come from a randomized experiment with a control group rather than from 
[L1308] an experiment without a control group, from an experiment that did not use ran￾domization to assign subjects to the treatments, or from an observational study.

[L1313] studies having randomization and control groups. This suggests that studies con￾ducted without randomization or without other ways to reduce bias may produce 
[L1314] results that tend to be overly optimistic.

[L1581] 4.4 Other Ways to Conduct Experimental 
[L1582] and Nonexperimental Studies
[L1583] In this chapter, we’ve learned the basics of ways to conduct nonexperimental 
[L1584] and experimental studies. This final section shows ways these methods are often 
[L1585] extended in practice so they are even more powerful. We’ll first learn about 
[L1586] alternatives to simple random sampling in sample surveys and then about types 
[L1587] of observational studies that enable us to study questions for which experiments 
[L1588] with humans are not feasible. Finally, we’ll learn how to study the effects of two 
[L1589] or more explanatory variables with a single experiment.
[L1590] Sample Surveys: Other Random Sampling 
[L1591] Designs Useful in Practice
[L1592] Simple random sampling gives every possible sample the same chance of selection. 
[L1593] In practice, more complex random sampling designs are often easier to implement 
[L1594] or are more efficient, requiring a smaller sampling size for the same precision. 
[L1595] Sometimes they are even preferable to simple random sampling.
[L1596] Cluster random sampling To use simple random sampling, we need a sampling 
[L1597] frame—the list of all, or nearly all, subjects in the population. In some cases, this 
[L1598] information is not available. It may be easier to identify clusters of subjects. A 
[L1599] study of residents of a country can identify counties or census tracts. A study of 
[L1600] students can identify schools. A study of the elderly living in institutions can iden￾tify nursing homes. We can obtain a sample by randomly selecting the clusters and 
[L1601] observing each subject in the clusters chosen.
[L1602] For instance, suppose you would like to sample about 1% of the families in

[L1847] Observational Studies and Causation
[L1848] Can we ever definitively establish causation with an observational study? No, we 
[L1849] cannot. For example, because the smoking and lung cancer study in Example 8 
[L1850] was observational, cigarette companies argued that a lurking variable could 
[L1851] have caused this association. So why are doctors so confident in declaring that 
[L1852] smoking causes lung cancer? For a combination of reasons: (1) Experiments 
[L1853] conducted using animals have shown an association, (2) in many countries, over 
[L1854] time, female smoking has increased relative to male smoking, and the incidence 
[L1855] of lung cancer has increased in women compared to men. Other studies, both 
[L1856] retrospective and prospective, have added more evidence. For example, when a 
[L1857] prospective study begun in 1951 with 35,000 doctors ended in 2001, researchers12
[L1858] estimated that cigarettes took an average of 10 years off the lives of smokers who 
[L1859] never quit. This study estimated that at least half the people who smoke from 
[L1860] youth are eventually killed by their habit.
[L1861] Most important, studies carried out on different populations of people have 
[L1862] consistently concluded that smoking is associated with lung cancer, even after ad￾justing for all potentially confounding variables that researchers have suggested. 
[L1863] As more studies are done that adjust for confounding variables, the chance that a 
[L1864] lurking variable remains that can explain the association is reduced. As a conse￾quence, although we cannot definitively conclude that smoking causes lung can￾cer, physicians will not hesitate to tell you that they believe it does. As do most 
[L1865] statisticians, including the four authors of this text!

[L2290] CHAPTER SUMMARY 
[L2291] This chapter introduced methods for gathering data.
[L2292] j An experiment assigns subjects to experimental conditions (such 
[L2293] as drug or placebo) called treatments. These are categories of 
[L2294] the explanatory variable. The outcome on the response variable 
[L2295] is then observed for each subject.
[L2296] j An observational study is a type of nonexperimental study 
[L2297] that observes subjects on the response and explanatory vari￾ables. The study samples the population of interest, but merely 
[L2298] observes rather than applies treatments to those subjects.
[L2299] Since association does not imply causation, with observational 
[L2300] studies we must be aware of potential lurking variables that 
[L2301] influence the association. In an experiment, a researcher uses 
[L2302] randomization in assigning experimental units (the subjects) 
[L2303] to the treatments. This helps balance the treatments on lurking 
[L2304] variables. A randomized experiment can provide support for 
[L2305] causation. To reduce bias, experiments should be double-blind, 
[L2306] with neither the subject nor the data collector knowing to which 
[L2307] treatment a subject was assigned.
[L2308] A sample survey is a type of nonexperimental study that takes 
[L2309] a sample from a population. Good methods for selecting samples 
[L2310] incorporate random sampling.
[L2311] j A simple random sample of n subjects from a population is one 
[L2312] in which each possible sample of size n has the same chance of 
[L2313] being selected.
[L2314] j A cluster random sample takes a simple random sample of 
[L2315] clusters (such as city blocks) and uses subjects in those clusters 
[L2316] as the sample.
[L2317] j A stratified random sample divides the population into separate 
[L2318] groups, called strata, and then selects a simple random sample 
[L2319] from each stratum.
[L2320] Be cautious of results from studies that use a convenience sample, 
[L2321] such as a volunteer sample, which Internet polls use. Even with 
[L2322] random sampling, biases can occur due to sample undercoverage, 
[L2323] nonresponse by many subjects in the sample, and responses that 
[L2324] are biased because of question wording or subjects’ lying.
[L2325] Most sample surveys take a cross section of subjects at a partic￾ular time. A census is a complete enumeration of an entire popula￾tion. Prospective studies follow subjects into the future, as is true 
[L2326] with many experiments. Medical studies often use retrospective
[L2327] observational studies, which look at subjects’ behavior in the past.
[L2328] j A case-control study is an example of a retrospective study. 
[L2329] Subjects who have a response outcome of interest, such as 
[L2330] cancer, serve as cases. Other subjects not having that outcome 
[L2331] serve as controls. The cases and controls are compared on an 
[L2332] explanatory variable, such as whether they had been smokers.
[L2333] A categorical explanatory variable in an experiment is also called a 
[L2334] factor. Multifactor experiments have at least two explanatory vari￾ables. With a completely randomized design, subjects are assigned 
[L2335] randomly to categories of each explanatory variable. Some designs 
[L2336] instead use blocks—sets of experimental units that are matched. 
[L2337] Matched-pairs designs have two observations in each block. Often 
[L2338] this is the same subject observed for each of two treatments, such as 
[L2339] in a crossover study.
[L2340] Data are only as good as the method used to obtain them. 
[L2341] Unless we use a good study design, conclusions may be faulty.

[L132] 4.1 Experimental and Observational Studies
[L133] We use statistics to learn about a population. The German and British studies in 
[L134] Example 1 examined subjects’ cell phone use and whether the subjects had brain 
[L135] or eye cancer. Since it would be too costly and time-consuming to seek out all
[L136] individuals in the populations of Germany or Great Britain, the researchers used 
[L137] samples to gather data. These studies, like many, have two variables of primary 
[L138] interest—a response variable and an explanatory variable. The response variable 
[L139] is whether a subject has cancer (eye or brain). The explanatory variable is the 
[L140] amount of cell phone use.
[L141] Types of Studies: Experimental and Observational
[L142] Some studies, such as Study 3 in Example 1, perform an experiment. Subjects are 
[L143] assigned to experimental conditions, such as when both cell phones are deacti￾vated (“off” condition) or the right cell phone is activated (“on” condition), that 
[L144] we want to compare on the response outcome. These experimental conditions are 
[L145] called treatments. They correspond to different values of the explanatory variable.

[L259] As we will soon discuss, an experimental study gives the researcher more control 
[L260] over outside influences. This control can allow more accuracy in studying the 
[L261] association.
[L262] Advantage of Experiments Over 
[L263] Observational Studies
[L264] In an observational study, lurking variables can affect the results. Study 1 in 
[L265] Example 1 found an association between cell phone use and eye cancer. However, 
[L266] there could be lifestyle, genetic, or health differences between the subjects with eye 
[L267] cancer and those without it, and between those who use cell phones a lot and those 
[L268] who do not. A lurking variable could affect the observed association. For example, 
[L269] a possible lifestyle lurking variable is computer use. Perhaps those who use cell 
[L270] phones often also use computers frequently. Perhaps high exposure to computer 
[L271] screens increases the chance of eye cancer. In that case, the higher prevalence of 
[L272] eye cancer for heavier users of cell phones could be due to their higher use of com￾puters, not their higher use of cell phones.
[L273] By contrast, an experiment reduces the potential for lurking variables to affect 
[L274] the results. Why? We’ll see that with a type of “random” selection to determine 
[L275] which subjects receive each treatment, we are attempting to form and balance 
[L276] groups of subjects receiving the different treatments; that is, the groups have 
[L277] similar distributions on other variables, such as lifestyle, genetic, or health char￾acteristics. For instance, suppose the researchers in cell phone Study 3 decided 
[L278] to have 24 subjects receive the “on” condition and 23 subjects receive the “off” 
[L279] condition instead of having each subject receive both treatments. The health of 
[L280] the subjects could be a factor in how the brain responds to the treatments and 
[L281] the amount of brain activity that appears on the scans. If we randomly determine 
[L282] which subjects receive the “on” condition and which do not, the two groups of 
[L283] subjects are expected to have similar distributions on health. One group will not 
[L284] be much healthier, on average, than the other group. When the groups are bal￾anced on a lurking variable, there is no association between the lurking variable 
[L285] and the explanatory variable (for instance, between health of the subject and 
[L286] whether the subject receives the “on” condition). Then, the lurking variable will 
[L287] not affect how the explanatory variable is associated with the response variable. 
[L288] One treatment group will not tend to have more brain activity because of health 
[L289] differences, on the average.
[L290] In Study 3, described in Example 1, by using the same subjects for both treat￾ments, the researchers were attempting to further control the variability from the 
[L291] subject’s health. In this experimental study, it was important to randomize the 
[L292] order in which the subject received the treatment.
[L293] Establishing cause and effect is central to science. But it’s not possible to 
[L294] establish cause and effect definitively with observational studies. There’s al￾ways the possibility that some lurking variable could be responsible for the 
[L295] association. If people who make greater use of cell phones have a higher rate of 
[L296] eye cancer, it may be because of some variable that we failed to measure in our 
[L297] study, such as computer use. As we learned in Section 3.4, association does not 
[L298] imply causation.
[L299] Because it’s easier to address the potential impact of lurking variables in an 
[L300] experiment than in an observational study, we can study the effect of an explan￾atory variable on a response variable more accurately with an experiment than 
[L301] with an observational study. With an experiment, the researcher has control over

[L330] Determining Which Type of Study Is Possible
[L331] If experiments are preferable, why ever conduct an observational study? Why 
[L332] bother to measure whether cell phone usage was greater for those with cancer 
[L333] than for those not having it? Why not instead conduct an experiment, such as 
[L334] the following: Pick half the students from your school at random and tell them to 
[L335] use a cell phone each day for the next 50 years. Tell the other half of the student 
[L336] body never to use cell phones. Fifty years from now, analyze whether cancer was 
[L337] more common for those who used cell phones.
[L338] There are obvious difficulties with such an experiment:
[L339] j It’s not ethical for a study to expose over a long period of time some of the 
[L340] subjects to something (such as cell phone radiation) that we suspect may be 
[L341] harmful.
[L342] j It’s difficult in practice to make sure that the subjects behave as told. How can 
[L343] you monitor them to ensure that they adhere to their treatment assignment 
[L344] over the 50-year experimental period?
[L345] j Who wants to wait 50 years to get an answer?
[L346] For these reasons, medical experiments are often performed over a short time 
[L347] period or often with exposure to treatments that would not be out of the ordinary 
[L348] (such as a one-time exposure to cell phone activity). To measure the effects on 
[L349] people of longer exposure to potentially harmful treatments, often the experiment 
[L350] uses animals such as mice instead of people. Because inferences about human 
[L351] populations are more trustworthy when we use samples of human subjects than 
[L352] when we use samples of animal subjects, scientists often resort to observational 
[L353] studies. Then we are not deliberately placing people in harm’s way, but observing 
[L354] people who have chosen on their own to take part in the activity of interest. In 
[L355] today’s information age, a lot of data is readily available to assist (or impede) 
[L356] people from making decisions about the relationship between variables. These 
[L357] data provide only observational comparisons. We’ll study methods for designing a 
[L358] good observational study in Section 4.4. This can yield useful information when an 
[L359] experiment is not practical.
[L360] Finally, another reason nonexperimental studies are common is that many 
[L361] questions of interest do not involve trying to assess causality. For instance, if we 
[L362] want to gauge the public’s opinion on some issue, or if we want to conduct a mar￾keting study to see how people rate a new product, it’s completely adequate to 
[L363] use a study that samples (appropriately) the population of interest.

[L619] 4.2 Good and Poor Ways to Sample
[L620] The sample survey is a common type of nonexperimental study. The first step of 
[L621] a sample survey is to define the population targeted by the study. For instance, 
[L622] the Gallup organization (www.gallup.com) conducts a monthly survey of about 
[L623] 1000 adult Americans. Gallup then reports the percentage of those sampled who 
[L624] respond “approve” when asked, “Do you approve or disapprove of the way [the 
[L625] current president of the United States] is handling his job as president?” If the 
[L626] sampling is conducted properly, this provides a good estimate of the approval 
[L627] rate within the entire population. The population consists of all adults living in 
[L628] the United States.
[L629] Sampling Frame and Sampling Design
[L630] Once you’ve identified the population, the second step is to compile a list of sub￾jects so you can sample from it. This list is called the sampling frame.
[L631] Sampling Frame
[L632] The sampling frame is the list of subjects in the population from which the sample is 
[L633] taken.
[L634] Ideally, the sampling frame lists the entire population of interest. In practice, 
[L635] as in a census, it’s usually hard to identify every subject in the population.
[L636] Suppose you plan to sample students at your school, asking students to com￾plete a questionnaire about various issues. The population is all students at the 
[L637] school. One possible sampling frame is the student directory. Another one is a list 
[L638] of registered students.
[L639] Once you have a sampling frame, you need to specify a method for selecting 
[L640] subjects from it. The method used is called the sampling design. Here’s one possi￾ble sampling design for sampling students at your school: You select all students 
[L641] in your statistics class. Do you think your class is necessarily reflective of the 
[L642] entire student body? Do you have a representative mixture of freshmen through 
[L643] seniors, males and females, athletes and nonathletes, working and nonworking 
[L644] students, political party affiliations, and so on? With this sampling design, it’s 
[L645] doubtful.
[L646] When you pick a sample merely by convenience, the results may not be rep￾resentative of the population. Some response outcomes may occur much more 
[L647] frequently than in the population, and some may occur much less. Consider a 
[L648] survey question about the number of hours a week that you work at an outside 
[L649] job. If your class is primarily juniors and seniors, they may be more likely to work 
[L650] than freshmen or sophomores. The mean response in the sample may be much 
[L651] larger than in the overall student population. Information from the sample may 
[L652] be misleading.

[L655] Simple Random Sampling
[L656] You’re more likely to obtain a representative sample if you let chance, rather than 
[L657] convenience, determine the sample. The sampling design should give each student 
[L658] an equal chance to be in the sample. It should also enable the data analyst to figure 
[L659] out how likely it is that descriptive statistics (such as sample means) fall close to 
[L660] corresponding values you’d like to make inferences about for the entire popula￾tion (such as population means). These are reasons for using random sampling.
[L661] You may have been part of a selection process in which your name was put in 
[L662] a box or hat along with many other names, and someone blindly picked a name 
[L663] for a prize. If the names were thoroughly mixed before the selection, this emu￾lates a random type of sampling called a simple random sample. 
[L664] Simple Random Sample
[L665] A simple random sample of n subjects from a population is one in which each possible 
[L666] sample of that size has the same chance of being selected.

[L792] Personal interview In a personal (face-to-face) interview, an interviewer asks 
[L793] prepared questions and records the subject’s responses. An advantage is that 
[L794] subjects are more likely to participate. A disadvantage is the cost. Also, some sub￾jects may not answer sensitive questions pertaining to opinions or lifestyle, such 
[L795] as alcohol and drug use, whether they have been victims of sexual abuse, or their 
[L796] HIV status that they might answer on a printed questionnaire.
[L797] Telephone interview A telephone interview is like a personal interview but 
[L798] conducted over the phone. A main advantage is lower cost because no travel is 
[L799] involved. A disadvantage is that the interview might have to be short. Subjects 
[L800] generally aren’t as patient on the phone and may hang up before starting or com￾pleting the interview.
[L801] Self-administered questionnaire Subjects are requested to fill out a questionnaire 
[L802] mailed, e-mailed, or otherwise available online. An advantage is that it is cheaper 
[L803] than a personal interview. A disadvantage is that fewer people tend to participate.
[L804] So which method is most used? Most major national polls that survey regularly 
[L805] to measure public opinion use the telephone interview. An example is the polls 
[L806] conducted by the Gallup organization. The General Social Survey is an exception, 
[L807] using personal interviews for its questionnaire, which is quite long.
[L808] For telephone interviews, since the mid-1980s, many sample surveys have used 
[L809] random digit dialing to select households. The survey can then obtain a sample 
[L810] without having a sampling frame. In the United States, typically the area code 
[L811] and the 3-digit exchange are randomly selected from the list of all such codes and 
[L812] exchanges. Then, the last four digits are dialed randomly, and an adult is selected 
[L813] randomly within the household. Although this sampling design incorporates 
[L814] randomness, it is not a simple random sample because each sample is not equally 
[L815] likely to be chosen. (Do you see why not? Does everyone have a telephone, or 
[L816] exactly one telephone?)

[L818] A variety of problems can cause responses from a sample to favor some parts of 
[L819] the population over others. Then, results from the sample are not representative 
[L820] of the population and are said to exhibit bias.

[L835] Sampling bias Bias may result from the sampling method. The main way 
[L836] this occurs is if the sample is not random. Another way it can occur is due to 
[L837] undercoverage—having a sampling frame that lacks representation from parts of 
[L838] the population. A phone survey using landlines will not reach homeless people, 
[L839] prison inmates, or people who don’t have landline phones. If its sampling frame 
[L840] consists of the names in a phone directory, it will not reach those who don’t have 
[L841] landlines. Most major polling agencies use randomized dialing. Responses by 
[L842] those who are not in the sampling frame might be quite different from those who 
[L843] are in the frame. Bias resulting from the sampling method, such as nonrandom 
[L844] sampling or undercoverage, is called sampling bias.
[L845] Nonresponse bias A second type of bias occurs when some sampled subjects 
[L846] cannot be reached or refuse to participate. This is called nonresponse bias. The 
[L847] subjects who are willing to participate may be different from the overall sample 
[L848] in some systematic way, perhaps having strong emotional convictions about the 
[L849] issues being surveyed. Even those who do participate may not respond to some 
[L850] questions, resulting in nonresponse bias due to missing data. All major surveys 
[L851] suffer from some nonresponse bias. The General Social Survey has a nonre￾sponse rate of about 20–30%. The nonresponse rate is much higher for many 
[L852] telephone surveys. By contrast, government-conducted surveys often have lower 
[L853] nonresponse rates. The Current Population Survey has a nonresponse rate of 
[L854] only about 7%. To reduce nonresponse bias, investigators try to make follow-up 
[L855] contact with the subjects who do not return questionnaires.
[L856] Results have dubious worth when there is substantial nonresponse. For instance, 
[L857] in her best-selling and controversial book Women and Love (1987), author and 
[L858] feminist Shere Hite presented results of a survey of adult women in the United 
[L859] States. One of her conclusions was that 70% of women who had been married at 
[L860] least five years have extramarital affairs. She based this conclusion on responses to 
[L861] questionnaires returned from a sample of 4500 women. This sounds impressively 
[L862] large. However, the questionnaire was mailed to about 100,000 women. We cannot 
[L863] know whether this sample of 4.5% of the women who responded is representative 
[L864] of the 100,000 who received the questionnaire, much less the entire population of 
[L865] adult American women. In fact, Hite was criticized for her research methodology 
[L866] of using a nonrandom sample and the large nonresponse rate.
[L867] Response bias A third type of potential bias is in the actual responses made. 
[L868] This is called response bias. An interviewer might ask the questions in a leading 
[L869] way, such that subjects are more likely to respond a certain way. Or, subjects may 
[L870] lie because they think their response is socially unacceptable, or they may give 
[L871] the response that they think the interviewer prefers.
[L872] If you design an interview or questionnaire, you should strive to construct 
[L873] questions that are clear and understandable. Avoid questions that are confusing, 
[L874] long, or leading. The wording of a question can greatly affect the responses. A 
[L875] Roper poll was designed to determine the percentage of Americans who ex￾press some doubt that the Holocaust occurred in World War II. In response to 
[L876] the question, “Does it seem possible or does it seem impossible to you that the 
[L877] Nazi extermination of the Jews never happened?” 22% said it was possible the 
[L878] Holocaust never happened. The Roper organization later admitted that the ques￾tion was worded in a confusing manner. When it asked, “Does it seem possible 
[L879] to you that the Nazi extermination of the Jews never happened, or do you feel 
[L880] certain that it happened?” only 1% said it was possible it never happened.4
